Desde que esta en Finca ella invierte el todo el préstamo en mercadería, ha aprendido a invertir, le gusta la unión  que hay entre las socias y la solidaridad en el Bancomunal.   
El sueño de Gloria  es estar tranquila en su casa, y dedicarse a su bodeguita.
texts.en:
Gloria is a member of the La Fortaleza community bank. She is married, 58 years old, and has five married children. Gloria used to be a street vendor, selling stockings from a cart in the market, but she had to stop working for a time when she suffered a slipped disk. Later, she decided to work at home, setting up a small grocery called Bodega Gloria which she has operated for two years. Gloria needs a 1000-soles loan to buy cold drinks, beer, milk and bags of sugar. Since starting at Finca, she's learned how to invest and she now invests all her borrowings in merchandise for the business. She likes the camaraderie of the group and the sense of solidarity that the community bank provides. Gloria's greatest hope is to be happy both at home and at her bodeguita.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise to resell.

loans.name: Caciana

texts.es: Caciana tiene 47 años, vive con su esposo Adolfo y sus hijos; Segundina D. 27, Elvis D. 23 y Adolfo D. 18 años en su casa propia en Lima, su hijo Alfredo, D. 31 vive en la ciudad D. Ayacucho. DesD. hace 7 años se dedica a la elaboración D. collares, anillos y aretes hechos a base D. piedras rústicas, mostacillas, semillas, etc, más conocido como el arte D. la “Bisutería”, actividad que realiza en su propia casa y ha significado su mayor fuente D. ingresos, ya que aunque su esposo trabaje D. chofer, a ella nunca le ha gustado depender D. él y siempre ha tratado D. solventar sus gastos y los D. su negocio. Además Caciana está acostumbrada a estar activa y esta es una buena manera D. trabajar y hacer que aflore toda su creatividad, ya que inventa nuevos modelos que son exportados, pues cuenta con un contacto que venD. toda su producción en el extranjero. Cuando tiene pedidos mayores, brinda empleo a sus amigas, ya que no se da abasto para realizarlos todos, entonces les paga un porcentaje D. sus ganancias para que la ayuden a producir. Pero este trabajo también tiene sus dificultades, ya que el esfuerzo que hace para lograr un buen acabado, ha deteriorado su vista, por lo que sus hijos ya no quieren que trabaje en este oficio, es por eso que en un futuro espera poner un taller que sólo administre y así no dejar D. dedicarse a esto que tanto le gusta. El dinero que solicita es para comprar mayor cantidad D. material para seguir inventando nuevos modelos D. collares, aretes y anillos, además D. cubrir su último pedido, el cual aún no ha terminado.
texts.en:
Caciana, 47, lives with her husband, Adolfo, and their children, Segundina, 27, Elvis, 23, and Adolfo, 18, in the house they own in Lima. Her son, Alfredo, 31, lives in the city of Ayachucho. For 7 years, she's earned a living making necklaces, rings and earrings from stones, beads, seeds, etc. or, in other words, practicing the art of making costume jewelry. She works at home and the business has become her main source of income. Even though her husband works, as a [bus?] driver, she's never wanted to depend on him and has always tried to cover her expenses and those of the business. Furthermore, Caciana is used to being busy and the business is a means of both earning a living and developing creatively. She invents new styles that she even exports because she has a contact who sells what she makes overseas. When she has large orders, she provides employment for her friends because can't cope with the workload. She pays them a percentage of her earnings. There are difficulties, though. The effort required to properly finish her products has damaged her eyesight. Her children don't want her to go on working and she hopes, in the future, to set up a small workshop that she would only manage, something that would allow her to still have a hand at a business that she very much enjoys. She's applying for a loan to buy larger quantities of materials so that she can go on creating new styles of necklaces, earrings and rings, as well as cover her last order which she still hasn't completed.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials for crafts business.

loans.name: Zula Saudah‘S Group

texts.en:
Saudah is 30 years of age, a single mother of three children, aged between 9 and 13. She owns a two-roomed house where she is living with four people, and she doesn’t take care of any additional family members. She doesn’t have access to electricity or piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Saudah sells charcoal at her house in Naguru, one of the city suburbs .She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work from suppliers who get the charcoal from the villages; that is how she earns her living. Her monthly expenses include rent for her residence, which functions as her place of work, and school fees for her children.

Saudah sells to all categories of people and works seven days week. She has done this business for over two years now This is her sixth loan since she joined MCDT, and she has been with MCDT for three years, working with the same group mates. Saudah wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es: Esperanza tiene 31 años, vive con su pareja Ladislao de 42, y sus hijos; ellos tienen un terreno propio, pero alquilan una casa que les sirve como taller para su negocio. Desde hace 10 años se ha venido dedicando a su taller de planchado y pintado de autos, decidieron incursionar en este negocio por las habilidades que tenían su esposo para el arreglo de autos, desde entonces han avanzado poco a poco con su negocio y hoy en día sus servicios son muy demandados, lo cual les llevó a contratar a dos jóvenes para que los ayuden. Por unidad y según el daño del vehículo, llegan a cobrar hasta 750 soles, lo cual es invertido en comprar planchas de metal y otros materiales para que el vehiculo quede en buenas condiciones. A Esperanza le gusta mucho su trabajo y siendo mujer no le ve impedimento para realizarlo, nos dice que prefiere más el trabajo duro en su taller que la labor de cocina en su hogar. Tanto ella como su esposo esperan seguir trabajando duro para salir adelante y mejorar su negocio. Con MFP, es su tercer préstamo y siempre ha sido muy puntual con todos los pagos de sus cuotas. El dinero que viene solicitando lo invertirá en la compra de material para arreglar vehículos; como planchas de metal, pintura, masilla, etc., y así poder brindar un mejor servicio.
texts.en:
Esperanza, 31, lives with her partner, Ladislao, 42, and their children. They have their own place but they rent a house that they use as a workshop for the business. For 10 years, Esperanza has operated an auto body repair and paint shop. They decided to start the business because her husband is skilled at repairing and painting auto bodies. The business has grown little by little and their services are now in such demand that they have two employees to help them. They charge up to 750 soles per vehicle, depending on what damage was done, some of which they spend on buying the materials they need to return the vehicle to good condition. Esperanza very much enjoys the work and being a woman has never been an impediment to doing it. She tells us that she prefers the hard work of the shop to the drudgery of her kitchen at home. Her husband, as well as she herself, hope to continue working hard to get ahead and improve the business. This is Esperanza's third MFP loan and she's always been punctual about repaying past loans. She will use this loan to buy materials for repairing vehicles: metal panels, paint, mastic, etc. so that the business can provide a better service.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for auto body repair service.

loans.name: Liliana

texts.es: Liliana tiene 35 años, vive con su pareja, Andrés de 42 años y sus hijos; Michael de 16, Yubitza de 13 y Didier de 2 añitos de edad, en su casa propia. Desde muy joven tuvo que trabajar muy duro para el bienestar de los suyos, ya que su madre llegó a la capital sin una moneda, teniendo que mantener a cuatro hijos entre los cuales se encontraba Liliana. Aun pequeña tuvo la necesidad de apoyar a su madre que se desempeñaba como costurera para poder mantenerlos, felizmente su arduo trabajo dio frutos y pudo comprar un pequeño terreno donde se trasladaron a vivir entre esteras, esto en el distrito de Ventanilla en Lima. Hoy en día, Liliana recuerda el esfuerzo de su madre, de sus hermanos y el de ella misma, por los diferentes oficios que tuvieron y tuvo que realizar para generar ingresos para su hogar, no hay oficio que haya dejado de lado, desde la confección de joyas (bisutería), venta de gelatina, organización de polladas (actividades donde se vende platos a base de pollo frito), venta de ropa, etc. y aún tiene muchas ideas de negocio en su mente. Actualmente tiene una pequeña bodega, la cual ha ido abasteciendo poco a poco para obtener los ingresos que necesita, Liliana piensa que no hay nada difícil en el trabajo, que uno simplemente debe ponerle muchas ganas y esfuerzo ya que el éxito viene detrás, ahora espera hacer crecer su negocio y seguir incursionando en nuevas ideas, ya que su imaginación no para cuando de hacer negocio se trata. Este es su cuarto préstamo en Microfinanzas PRISMA, y siempre ha sido muy puntual en todos sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará mayor cantidad productos para implementar su tienda; como comestibles, gaseosas, etc. así como vitrinas, las cuales le sirvan para mostrar mejor sus productos a su clientela.
texts.en:
Liliana, 35, lives with her children: Michael is 16; Yubitza is 13; and Didier is 2. They also live with the children’s father, Andrés, who is 42. They have their own house. Since she was very young she has had to work very hard for the well being of her family. Her mother arrived in the capital with no money, and she had to take care of her four children. Even though she was little, Liliana had to help her mother, who worked as a seamstress, to support her family. Happily, her hard work paid off. She was able to buy a small piece of land where they lived in the swamps in the Ventanilla district of Lima. Now, Liliana remembers the efforts her mother, her siblings, and she made in the different jobs they had to do to generate income for their home. There is no job that they would not do: from making jewelry; selling gelatin; organizing fried chicken dinners; selling clothes; etc. She has even more business ideas in her head. She now has a small store, which little by little she has been stocking, in order to get the income she needs. Liliana thinks that it is not hard work. One simply needs to have the desire, put forth the effort, and success will follow. She now hopes to have her business grow and continue investing in new ideas. Her imagination has no end where business is concerned. This is her fourth micro loan with Prisma. She has always made her payments on time. With the loan she will buy more products to put in her store, such as food, soft drinks, etc. She will also buy display cases to better show her products to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Lorenzo

texts.es: Lorenzo tiene 54 años, vive con su esposa y sus hijos; Geral de 16 años y Dayana de 9 años, ya que sus hijas Mitzi de 30 y Lisset de 25 conformaron sus propias familias. Él se viene dedicando al manejo de un minibús brindado transporte de pasajeros con diferentes rutas en la ciudad de Lima, trabajo que le significa una mejora en la calidad de vida de su familia. Aún así, su esposa lo ayuda en los gastos con el pequeño negocio que tiene en su casa, que es una bodega - restaurante, donde atiende a los pensionistas que anticipan la paga para que ella les prepare sus deliciosos platillos, siendo un buen negocio, ya que sabe cuántas porciones preparar sin desperdiciar o sobrar, además que la cocina le encanta y ella no lo ve como un trabajo sino como un pasatiempo que le gusta realizar. Es así que trabajando unidos sacaron adelante a sus cuatro hijos, los cuales ahora los apoyan en sus momentos libres. Lorenzo y su esposa esperan en el futuro hacer crecer su bodega e implementar mejor su restaurante para así cubrir los gastos de sus hijos con los que viven actualmente. Este es su primer préstamo individual con MFP, y sus antecedentes son de un cliente muy responsable y puntual. Con el dinero solicitado hará refaccionar algunas fallas del minibus que maneja y apoyará a su esposa para que compre más cantidad de ingredientes para la preparación de los platillos que ofrece en su restaurante.
texts.en:
Lorenzo is 54. He lives with his wife and children. Geral is 16, Dayana is 9. Mitzi, 30 and Lisset, 25 have started their own families. Lorenzo drives a minibus for people throughout the city of Lima for a living. His job gives his family a better quality of life. Even so, his wife helps with expenses with the small warehouse-restaurant business she operates from home. Because it is a good business, retirees go to her restaurant where she waits on them and prepares delicious meals. Lorenzo's wife knows the just right portions to serve. She loves to work in the kitchen and doesn't consider it a chore. By working together Lorenzo and his wife were able to get their four children ahead. Now, their four children help them out whenever they can. In the future, Lorenzo and his wife want to expand the warehouse and improve their restaurant in order to cover the costs of their children, who live them. This is his first individual loan with MFP, and his record is that of a responsible and punctual client. With the loan, Lorenzo will make small repairs to the minibus and will support his wife in buying more ingredients for the dishes she serves in her restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Jonathan Bradshaw, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Minibus repair and purchase of ingredients for wife's restaurant

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.es: Nicolás es un joven muy trabajador, vive con su pareja, sus dos pequeños hijos y su hermana en su propia casa. Desde muy pequeño le gustaron los trabajos manuales, es por eso que aprendió las nociones básicas de la carpintería, las cuales con el tiempo llegó a perfeccionar, ahora se dedica a la elaboración y venta de guitarras las cuales elabora en triplay o madera según el pedido que le hagan, pero él solo elabora el armazón ya que luego sus sobrinos proceden al pintado y barnizado de las mismas para lograr el acabado final. A él le gusta mucho su trabajo, ya que puede realizarlo desde su casa y así estar al pendiente de sus hijos los cuales están en la etapa escolar y necesitan mucho de su ayuda y orientación en las tareas que les encomiendan en el colegio. Es por eso, que quiere seguir incrementando su producción y también el tamaño de su taller, para consolidarse en un futuro como el mejor fabricante de guitarras de su zona, aunque sabe que el camino será duro, ya que no todo es fácil como parece y debe ser muy detalloso al elaborar las guitarras y darles el acabado final para que suenen y luzcan como debe de ser. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, fue aconsejado por su hermana, ya que ella pertenece desde hace muchos años a un banco comunal de la misma institución y siempre le ha ido muy bien. Con el dinero solicitado comprará grandes cantidades de planchas de triplay y de madera para incrementar su producción.
texts.en:
Nicolás is a hard-working young man. He lives with his girlfriend, their two children, and his sister in his own house. Since he was very little he enjoyed working with his hands. It is because of this that he learned the basic concepts of carpentry, which over time he has been able to perfect. Today, he uses these skills to design and build guitars, which he manufactures from plywood or hardwood, according to the customer's order. He only builds the body of the guitar, then his nephews apply paint and varnish to achieve a finished product. Nicolas likes his work very much, since he is able to do it from his home, and can thus keep an eye on his sons, both of whom are in school and need lots of help and guidance from him with their schoolwork. It is because of this that he wants to continue expanding his production and also the size of his workshop, in hope of solidifying his position as the best guitar manufacturer of his area. He knows the path will be difficult, since nothing is as easy as it seems, and he realizes he must be very careful and detailed in building his guitars, paying attention to all the final touches, so that they sound and shine as well as they ought to. This is his first loan with MFP. He was encouraged to take a loan by his sister, since she has belonged for many years to a communal bank from the same institution, and always come out well from her involvement with the bank. With the money that he asks for he will buy large quantities of sheets of plywood and hardwood, so that he can increase his production.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de madera

loans.name: Immaculate Nanfuka‘S Group

texts.en:
Immaculate is 38 years of age, married with four children aged between 10 and 16. All her children go to school. She owns a three-roomed house where she is living with six people, and she doesn’t take care of any additional family members. She has access to electricity and piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Immaculate sells fruits and vegetables in Ndeeba Market, in one of the city suburbs. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work from suppliers who get the goods from villages; that is how she earns her living. Her monthly expenses include rent for her place of work and school fees for her children.

Immaculate sells to all categories of people and works six days week. She has done this business for over four years now This is her twelfth loan since she joined MCDT, and she has been with MCDT for six years, working with the same group mates. Immaculate wants to use this loan to buy more fruits and vegetables right from the farmers and partly to pay school fees for her children She is aspiring of seeing her business growing bigger and owning permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more fruits direct from the farmers

loans.name: Chahongir

texts.ru: Чахонгир занимается перевозкой людей на своей собственной машине – он таксист. Ему 32 года, женат и имеет троих детей. Жена нигде не работает и находится дома и смотрит за детьми. Чахонгир кроме такси по выходным дня занимается куплей продажей сухофруктов. Для расширения бизнеса собирается получить займ на КИВА.
texts.en:
Chahongir transports people in his personal vehicle – he is a taxi driver. He is 32 years old, he is married and has three children. His wife does not have a job and stays at home and watches the children. Chahongir in addition to the taxi purchases and sells dried fruit on the weekends. In order to grow his business he plans to take out a loan from KIVA.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grow business

loans.name: Bahtiyor

texts.ru: Бахтиер не имеет постоянной работы и занимается бизнесом. По выходным базарным дням он выходит на базар и занимается куплей продажей сухофруктов. Ему 32 года, женат, трое детей. Жена нигде не работает так как в регионе их проживания нет нормальных рабочих мест. Бахтиер кроме бизнеса еще работает в качестве такси. Бахтиер хочет получить займ на КИВА для расширения своего бизнеса.
texts.en:
Bahtiyor does not have a steady job and is a businessman. On weekend market days he goes to the market and purchases and sells dried fruits. He is 32 years old, is married and has three children. His wife does not have a job since in their region there are no normal work places. Bahtiyor in addition to his business works as a taxi driver. Bahtiyor would like to get a loan on KIVA in order to expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grow business

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
Víctor es chofer propietario, tiene una vagoneta que trabaja como radio taxi en la empresa Apolo, y su esposa es comerciante.
Tiene tres hijos que son independientes y los ingresos que genera por el servicio de transporte y la actividad de su esposa es para la sobre vivencia de su familia.
Vive en la zona de Villa Armonia de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa propia.
El crédito será destinado para capital de inversión (mantenimiento completo del vehiculo).
Es la cuarta vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, y la segunda vez que requiere el apoyo de Kiva. Es cliente nuestro desde el año 2006.
texts.en:
Víctor is a taxi driver and has his own station wagon, which he uses as his taxi for the company Apolo, His wife is a businesswoman. He has three grown children, and the income he makes from his transport service and from his wife's job goes toward the family's survival. He lives in the Villa Armonia area of La Paz, in his own home.

This loan will be used to invest in the complete maintenance of his vehicle. This is Victor's fourth loan with Impro (a Kiva partner), and the second time he has sought the support of Kiva. He has been a client since 2006.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maintenance of his taxi

loans.name: Yoni

texts.en:
Yoni is a member of the Virgen de Asunta Village Bank and lives in the town of Calca, about an hour outside the city of Cusco. Yoni is 70 years old and widowed with four children, all adults. She also has eight grandchildren. Two of her children, Manuel and Biqui, are also members of her village bank as well as Kiva clients. Yoni is upbeat and spunky, and has the energy of someone half her age.

Yoni raises cows, pigs, rabbits and hens. She also grows corn, squash, potatoes and other vegetables on her land. Yoni has worked on her family farm since she got married many years ago. Her main source of income is selling milk from her four cows. She sells to PRONA, a government-sponsored organization that gives free milk to poor schoolchildren. Each liter sells for 1.70 soles (US 55 cents). Yoni employs anywhere from zero to five field workers on her farm at one time, depending on the season. Right now, she has four or five workers, since it is corn-harvesting season.

Yoni is requesting a loan of 1500 soles to improve her stable and pay her field workers for the corn harvest. She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time.

loans.use: Pay farmhands for corn harvest

loans.name: Sirari Group

texts.es: El grupo “Sirari” esta representado por la señora Maria y conformada por 14 miembros los cuales se dedican a diferentes actividades como la venta D. comida, ropa, pan, abarrotes y entre los varones se dedican a actividades como la sastrería, moto taxista, venta D. ladrillos y al servicio D. transporte público D. pasajeros. Dentro del ámbito D. la prestación D. servicios y el comercio existe mucha competencia donD. aquel que brinda un mejor servicio o un mejor producto es el que genera mayores ganancias; es por esta razón que el grupo adquiere el financiamiento para la compra D. insumos, herramientas y materiales para poner a la venta un producto D. calidad y brinda un servicio mas eficiente y D. calidad. Una mayoría D. los miembros va cursando su segundo ciclo demostrando cumplimiento y responsabilidad en los pagos efectuados demostrando ser capaces y con grandes expectativas D. crecimiento.
texts.en:
The Sirari group is represented by Maria and its 14 members operate businesses selling food, clothing, bread and groceries; the men work as tailors, cab drivers, brick salesmen and bus drivers. There is a lot of competition for the products and services offered by the group's businesses and the businesses that proviD. better products or services are the ones that generate the highest earnings. That's why the group acquired funding for the supplies, tools and materials they need to bring products of quality to market and to be able to proviD. the best, most efficient service. A majority of the members are starting a second lending cycle and have a history of repaying their loans on time.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital.

loans.name: Reynita De Belen De Ccorao Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “REYNITA D. BELEN D. CCORAO”, tiene fundado 6 años, y se encuentra ubicado en la comunidad D. Corroa, ubicada a 30 minutos D. la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestros socios, tienen todos como principal actividad la agricultura, alternando está y en época D. secas, la gran mayoría D. socios se dedican a la venta D. artesanía, por ser Corroa una parada obligada a la ruta del complejo turístico D. Pisac, Corroa es tierra D. artesanos, allí hay talleres enteros D. producción D. artesanías y tejidos en lanas D. alpaca y oveja D. mantillas, gorros para el frío, guantes, ponchos, chalinas, chompas y mucho más; por lo que casi toda la población vive D. la venta D. sus artesanías, otro sector minorista tiene tiendas pequeñas en la que venden agua mineral, galletas, gaseosas, chocolates y alternan con su artesanía, para lo cual los socios requieren el préstamo, ellos necesitan reinvertir en su mercadería, por que la temporada alta del turismo ya empezó.

Los socios se encuentran sumamente agradecidos y valoran el préstamo que se les otorga debido a que en su localidad no encuentran la presencia D. una banca financiera, por lo que ellos se comprometen a cumplir con el pago total D. su préstamo en el plazo programado.
texts.en:
The community bank “Reynita D. Belen D. Ccorao" was founded 6 years ago and is located in the Corroa community in the city of Cusco.

Our members are all involved in agriculture, and during the dry season, the vast majority of the members sell artwork, as Corroa is an obligatory stop in the touristic route through Pisac. Corroa is a land of artisans. There are entire workshops of handicrafts and Alpaca wool fabrics, laces, hats for the cold weather, gloves, ponchos, scarves, sweaters and much more. Almost everyone in the village lives off of the sales of their handicrafts. A minority sector has small shops which sell mineral water, cookies, soft drinks, chocolates, and alternate this activity with their crafts. The loan is needed to invest in merchandise, as the high season for tourists has already begun.

The group members are extremely thankful for the loan they will be granted, as in their area they have not been able to find a financing institution. They promise to repay the entire loan amount on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more supplies for their handiwork and to buy seeds and dry grains

loans.name: Dioudé

texts.fr: Dioudé T. est un pére de famille koldois qui travaille dans le secteur alimentaire. Il achéte du bétail sur pied et chaque matin, il en abatte pour revendre la viande aux populations au niveau de son étal en abri de fortune. Il est marié et pére de cinq(05) dont trois garçons et deux filles. Sa clientéle est trés large car il s'est établi au coeur d'un quartier populaire de kolda/ C'est sa seule activité et cela lui permet de subvenir tant bien que mal aux besoins de sa famille. Il aimerait pouvoir disposer de plus de moyens pour mieux satisfaire la demande et construire un abri acceptable.
texts.en:
Dioudé T. is a father of a Kolda family who works in the food sector. He buys livestock, and each morning he slaughters them and sells the meat out of his makeshift covered stall. He is married and the father of five children, three boys and two girls. His customer base is very large because he got established in the heart of a highly-populated district of Kolda. This business is his only work, and it enables him more or less to provide for his family. He would like to have more funds available in order to satisfy the demand better and to build acceptable shelter.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy livestock for producing meat

loans.name: Las Andantes 2 Group

texts.es: El grupo “ Las Andantes 2”  esta representado por la señora Guadalupe e integrada por 13 miembros los cuales se dedican a actividades comerciales como a la venta D. cosméticos, condimentos, ropa y comida entre los varones se dedican al transporte público y a la construcción D. viviendas. Como es común en un amplio mercado siempre existe la competencia D. productos, es por esta razón que los miembros del grupo desean el financiamiento para mejorar la calidad D. sus productos y poder competir con el resto del mercado consiguiendo así un mejor ingreso diario para poder cumplir con sus obligaciones y brindar a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida. Para una mayoría D. los miembros este es su segundo ciclo demostrando ser capaces D. poder  cumplir con sus obligaciones puntualmente.
texts.en:
Ms. Guadalupe represents the group “ Las Andantes 2.” The group has 13 members who work in a variety of areas like: selling cosmetics, condiments, clothing, and food. The men work in public transportation and home construction. As is common in a large market, there is always a lot of competition among products. This is the reason that the members of the group want a loan. They want to improve the quality of their products and be able to compete with the rest of the market. And in this way get a better daily income so they can meet their obligations and offer their families a better quality of life. For the majority of members, this is the second cycle showing that they are capable of being able to meet their obligations punctually.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Manuel Genaro

texts.en:
Manuel is a member of the Virgen Asunta Village Bank in the town of Urco, just outside the city of Calca and about one hour from the city of Cusco. Manuel is 48 years old and married with one young daughter (pictured below—her head was shaved to get rid of head lice).

Manuel has a small dairy farm with 36 cows, which he has had for the past four years. Prior to that, he worked with his mother, Yoni, on her dairy farm. Manuel sells milk to PRONA, a government program that provides free milk to poor schoolchildren. The program buys his milk for 1.70 soles per liter (US 55 cents). Manuel produces about 300 liters of milk per day.

Manuel is requesting a loan of 2000 soles to buy cornhusks to store in his grain silo to feed his cows. He expects this amount to fill an entire silo of 200 cubic meters. Each silo will last him for about six months. Manuel wants to continue to buy more cows and expand his farm. His goal is to eventually produce 1000 liters of milk per day.

Manuel has pledged to repay his loan in full and on time.

loans.use: Buy cornhusks to feed cows

loans.name: Biqui Mirella

texts.en:
Biqui is a member of the Virgen Asunta Village Bank in the town of Urcos, just outside the city of Calca and about an hour from the city of Cusco. Biqui is a spunky, assertive woman and is often the center of attention, joking around with her loan officer and other group members. She is 44 years old and divorced with two children, both of whom are about to complete their university studies. Her daughter studies law, while her son studies marketing. She is clearly very proud of them both.

Biqui has a small dairy farm with more than 30 milk cows. She milks about 280 liters of milk each day, which she sells to PRONA, a government program that provides free milk to schoolchildren, as well as to individuals in the cities of Cusco and Urubamba. Each liter sells for 1.70 soles (US 55 cents). Biqui has one farmhand to help her run the farm, and she hires more help if she needs it, depending on the season. Biqui has always worked on a farm; her mother, Yoni, raised the children on her dairy farm. She also studied to be a chef and worked in restaurants for many years, but she has since decided to dedicate herself to the farm 100 percent.

Biqui is requesting a loan of 1500 soles to buy corn husks to feed to her cattle as well as to pay for tractor rental and fuel. She has been working with Asociacion Arariwa for eight years now, and has proved to be a responsible client. Microloans have allowed her to buy an additional three cows and a lot of cow feed over the years, she says. She has pledged to repay this loan on time and in full.

loans.use: Buy corn husks to feed cattle

loans.name: Susan's Group

texts.en:
Susan is a 23-year-old single woman. She supports her parents with her clothing shop. Susan has been running her clothing shop alone for 1.5 years. She says that people prefer her shop over other shops because she talks to her customers very nicely.

Susan is requesting a loan of 1.1 million USH. She will use this loan to pay an installment on her rent. Each month Susan must pay 700,000 USH in rent on her shop. She will also purchase some stock for her store. With her loan she will be able to buy 5 dozen dresses, 2 dozen trousers, and 2 dozen tops.

Susan dreams of some day being able to sell 10 dozen items per day. She says that if she is able to do this it will help her achieve her dream of buying a house and a car.

loans.use: To purchase 5 dozen dresses, 2 dozen trousers, 2 dozen tops, and pay some rent.

loans.name: Cotoca Group

texts.es: El grupo “Cotoca” esta representado por la señora Cecilia e integrado por doce personas D. las, dos D. las cuales son hombres y diez mujeres,  todos ellos se dedican a diferentes actividades comerciales para generar ingresos como la venta D. abarrotes, empanadas en instituciones educativas, ropa y entre los varones se dedican a la contracción D. viviendas y a la plomería. Como en todo ámbito comercial siempre existe la competencia D. productos en el mercado pero cada uno D. los miembros sabe como vencer los obstáculos. El destino del financiamiento es para la compra materiales e insumos para mejorar sus productos y para la mejora D. herramientas D. trabajo para brindarles un mejor ingreso económico y para poder darles a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida. Una mayoría D. los miembros del grupo obtienen por primera vez un préstamo bajo esta modalidad pero son gente responsable que conoce D. sus obligaciones ya que D. ello depenD. el progreso D. sus familias.
texts.en:
Ms. Cecilia represents the group “Cotoca." The group has 12 members, 2 of whom are men, and 10 of whom are women. They each have different ways of earning a living like selling groceries, selling empanadas in educational institutions, and selling clothing. The men make a living in home construction and plumbing. As with all commercial areas, there is always competition among products in the markets, but each member knows how to overcome this obstacle. The loans will be used to buy materials and supplies to improve their products and work tools so they can increase their incomes and give their families a better quality of life. For most of the members of this group, this is the first time they have applied for a loan in this way, but they are responsible people who know what their obligations are since their family’s progress depends on it.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Rocio

texts.en:
Rocio is the secretary of the Virgen Asunta Village Bank, a group from the town of Urco, located just outside the city of Calca and about an hour from the city of Cusco. Rocio is 48 years old and is married. She used to work in education as an administrator, but didn’t like the work very much. She quit her job when she was invited to travel to England to work on a cruise ship teaching Spanish to children, but before she left she met her husband, a schoolteacher who lived next door to her, and decided to stay in Peru. They eventually married, and she now has her own small business selling clothing and makeup by catalog.

Rocio is requesting a loan of 1000 soles. She will lend half of the money to her husband so that he can pay for some paperwork he needs in order to receive his master’s degree, and will use the other half of the money to buy clothing and makeup. The couple will repay the loan together. Rocio has pledged to repay her loan in full and on time.

loans.use: Pay for husband's master's degree, buy clothing and makeup

loans.name: Yenny Maria

texts.en:
Yenny is a member of the Virgen Asunta Village Bank in the town of Urco, just outside the larger town of Calca and about an hour from the city of Cusco. Yenny is 29 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their two young children. Yenny buys dried corn from local farmers, which she then sells to intermediaries for export. She has been in this business for the past five years, and has been a client of Asociacion Arariwa for about the same time. She started out with a loan of just 300 soles (US $95) and has been able to expand her business significantly since then.

Yenny is requesting a loan of 3000 soles to buy 1000 kilos of dried corn. She has a vision to start a new business in the future. She wants to open a small pharmacy and Internet cafe in Calca. The town currently lacks these services. Yenny has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time.

loans.use: Buy 1000 kilos of dried corn from farmers to export.

loans.name: Tropical Group

texts.es: El banco comunal “Tropical” esta representado por el señor Abad y conformado por 14 miembros dedicados en su mayoría al comercio de abarrotes, comida, cosméticos, ropa y al servicio de transporte público de pasajeros y a la elaboración de pan. Como en todo rubro comercial siempre existe la competencia de productos de calidad es por esta razón que los miembros del grupo desean adquirí mas capital para la compra de maquinarias y herramientas para la elaboración de productos así como para la compra de insumos y materiales para su comercialización. El desarrollo que tuvieron estas familias integradas e el grupo se debe precisamente a que van ya cursando su quinto ciclo juntos demostrando tener ganas de trabajar y responsabilidad para cumplir no solo con la institución si no el compromiso que tienen con el grupo para salir adelantes y seguir progresando juntos.
texts.en:
Mr. Abad represents the communal bank “Tropical.” The group has 14 members. Most sell groceries, food, and cosmetics, or work in public transportation or bread baking. As with all commercial areas, there is always competition among quality products. This is why this group's members want to acquire more capital. They want to buy equipment and tools to make products and to buy supplies and materials for marketing their products. The development that the families that are part of this group have had is precisely because they are already on their 5th cycle demonstrating together their desire to work. And also demonstrating their responsibility in meeting their obligations, not only with the institution, but also with the commitments they have with the group to get ahead and to continue progressing together.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Elisa Del Carmen

texts.es:
ELISA D. CARMEN T. D. A., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Talentosas”  con su local ubicado en el Jr. Salaverry Nº 635 D. Distrito de Calleria; tiene 44 años, tiene 1 hijo menor y 2 ya adultos. Está separada de su esposo.

Ella se dedica al alquiler de este amplio local comercial ubicado en el centro de la ciudad; es socia en Manuela Ramos desde hace 1 año, su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles, lo utilizo para el remodelamiento de su local que ahora alquila.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00 Nuevos Soles, piensa hincar otro negocio de compra y venta de madera, para lo cual se siente preparada y con todas las ganas de mejorar su nivel económico.

Comenta: “Me Agrada la forma de trabajo de Manuela Ramos, el sistema que tiene, el orden, así como las orientaciones que dan, he puesto en práctica algunos consejos que me ayudaron a mejorar mi empresa.
texts.en:
Elisa D. Carmen T. D. A. belongs to the “Mujeres Talentosas” community bank. Her business is located at Jr. Salaverry Nº 635 in the Calleria district. She is 44, has a minor son, and two adult children. She is separated from her husband. Her business is renting this spacious commercial business in the center of the city. She has been a member of Manuela Ramos for 1 year. Her first loan was for 300 PEN which she used to remoD. the location she now rents. With a loan of 1,500 PEN she will launch another business, the buying and selling of wood. She feels prepared for this, and she has a great desire to improve her economic level. She says, “I am happy with the way Manuela Ramos works, the system they have, and their order. I have put some of their suggestions into practice, and they helped me improve my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wholesale wood

loans.name: Ada Ysabel

texts.en:
Ada is a member of the Virgen Asunta Village Bank in the town of Urco, located just outside the larger town of Calca and about an hour from the city of Cusco. She is 31 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their 7-month old baby boy. Ada runs a tire-changing shop in Calca, where she employs one person. Right now she just sells and changes tires, but she hopes to expand and start doing oil changes as well. Ada also works as an administrator for a local NGO that works in water sanitation; she does the organization’s accounting each month, and turns in her report on or before the 4th of every month. 

Ada is requesting a loan of 1000 soles (PEN-nuevo sol) for a new business that she is planning to launch. She wants to open a very small factory to make her own sodas and bottled water. She saw one such business about four years ago and has been planning to open her own drink business since then. She plans to sell her drinks in the valley area outside of Cusco. She says that market studies have shown that people in that area would be the most receptive to her products. She plans to start with sodas, then move on to water, carbonated water and lemon-flavored water. Ada will use her 1000 PEN (USD 325) to buy water tanks and installation tubes. 

Ada became an Arariwa client when she was 18 and worked with the institution for three years. She returned about two years ago because she likes its mandatory savings program (in which clients are obliged to save 5% of their loan amount in a collective savings account). She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time.

loans.use: Buy water tanks and installation tubing for a new business manufacturing drinks and carbonated water.

loans.name: Walter

texts.es: Walter tiene 46 años, vive con su pareja y su hijo Jean Carlos de 16 años en su casa propia. Él es taxista, actividad que realiza desde hace 10 años, porque siempre le ha gustado conducir, recuerda que comenzó desde los 15 años, siendo cobrador de pasajes en los ómnibus que realizaban su servicio de transporte por diferentes rutas de la ciudad de Lima. Desde ahí tuvo la iniciativa de aprender a manejar y así lo hizo, es por eso que hoy en día se dedica netamente a esta actividad, ya que él no se visualiza a sí mismo realizando otra labor que no tenga que ver con el transporte. Por otro lado, las cosas no siempre son fáciles ya que muchas veces se encuentra con personas que no le quieren pagar y tampoco está libre de los riesgos que están a la orden del día, además la congestión vehicular, pero aún así el ama su trabajo y quiere seguir progresando, aunque el carro que maneja actualmente no es propio él tiene planes de refaccionar el auto que compró hace algunos años atrás, que es un poco antiguo pero que con un buen arreglo quedaría en optimas condiciones para trabajar y ahorrarse el dinero el pago del alquiler del vehículo con el que trabaja actualmente. Walter tiene tres préstamos en Microfinanzas PRISMA y siempre se ha caracterizado por ser muy puntual en sus pagos. Con este dinero arreglará su propio carro haciéndole un planchado y pintado para dejarlo operativo y empezar a trabajar con él.
texts.en:
Walter is 46 years old and lives with his partner and his son Jean Charles, who is 16, in his own home. He is a taxi driver, a job that he has done for 10 years because he has always enjoyed driving. He remembers that he began at age 15 as a ticket collector on the bus that provided transport service on the various routes in the city of Lima. From there he took the initiative to learn to drive and did it. Because of that he works today with distinction in this field and does not see himself undertaking another line of work that does not have to do with transport. On the other hand, things are not always easy and he often encounters people that do not want to pay nor is the work free of the risks that are the order of the day, plus the traffic congestion. But even so, he loves his work and wants to continue progressing. Although the car that he now drives is not his own, he has plans to repair a car he bought several years ago. It is a little old, but with good repairs it would be in good condition to work and save the money he pays to rent the car he now drives. Walter has had three loans with PRISMO Microfinance and has always been characterized by being very punctual in his payments. With this money he will fix his own car, doing some body work and painting it to make it operational and begin working with it.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair his own car so he can stop renting one.

loans.name: Fanny Beatriz

texts.en:
Fanny is a member of the Virgen Asunta Village Bank in the town of Urco, located just outside the larger town of Calca and about an hour from the city of Cusco. Fanny is 29 years old and is the single mother of two school-age children. Until recently, Fanny worked in a local restaurant. She decided to quit because of some health problems with ulcers and gastritis. She is now launching her own business selling milk in the plaza of the nearby city of Urubamba. Fanny has two cows of her own, which produce about 20 liters of milk per day. She buys an additional 30 liters from other local farmers. She buys the milk for 1.30 soles (US 42 cents) per liter and resells it for 1.40 soles (US 45 cents) per liter. Fanny works seven days a week at this business. 

Fanny is requesting a loan of 1000 soles (US $325), with which she plans to buy a young calf that will eventually produce milk (in about two years). She has been taking out loans from Asociacion Arariwa for about three years. Her very first loan was for 300 soles (US $95). Fanny has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time.

loans.use: To buy a calf to raise for milk production

loans.name: Khady Sow

texts.fr: Madame Khady Sow G. est une femme Sénégalaise qui veut acheter les poussins pour les élever.  Elle a commencé de faire le commerce depuis 1999.  Elle faisait la navette entre la Mauritanie, Mali, et Gambie pour acheter des produits (cosmétiques, tissus, savons) pour les revendre.  Depuis 2006, elle travaille aux Eaux et Forets de Thiès comme secrétaire.   Avec ce prêt, elle envisage de se lancer dans le commerce d’avicole.   Elle est âgée de 34 et elle est mariée.  Elle habite à Thiès, une ville vers 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.  Elle va utiliser les revenus de son entreprise pour aider dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
Khady Sow G. is a Senegalese woman who would like to buy chicks to raise them. She started business in 1999. She was travelling between Mauritania, Mali and the Gambia to buy goods (cosmetics, fabric, soap) to retail them. Since 2006, she has been working as a secretary at the Water and Forest agency of Thies. With this loan, she plans to start a poultry business. She is 34 years old and she is married. She lives in Thies, 70 kilometers away from Dakar, the capital city of Senegal. She will use her business profits for her daily expenses.

Translated from French by Anne-Laure B.

loans.use: To buy chicks

loans.name: Similla Group

texts.es: El grupo “Similla” esta representado por la señora Maritza y conformado por 12 miembros los cuales se dedican actividades comerciales en especial D. verduras frescas, fruta, comida, venta D. edredones y a actividades como la construcción D. viviendas. Dentro D. estos rubros D. venta D. verduras existe mucha competencia ya que algunos productores prefieren salir a vender sus productos ellos mismos que a los revendedores causando competencia en los precios, es por esta razón que los socios (as) requieren del financiamiento para comprar los productos desD. su lugar D. origen a un precio mas bajo para poder competir en el mercado y también para la adquisición D. materiales y herramientas que ayuden al trabajo D. los miembros del grupo que se dedican a otras actividades. Una mayoría D. los miembros del grupo conocen el trabajo con grupos solidarios ya que trabajaron anteriormente con instituciones similares a la fundación  Agrocapital, por lo que conocen D. la responsabilidad y compromiso que se requiere para que el grupo pueda adquirir los fondos y poder así realizar un trabajo D. mejor calidad para ingresos mayores que coadyuva al mejoramiento D. la calidad D. vida D. sus familias.
texts.en:
The group "Similla" is represented by Mrs. Martiza and formed by 12 members who work selling fresh vegetables, fruits, food, bed sheets and other activities like construction of houses. There is a lot a competition on vegetables prices, this is why the members need a loan to buy the products at lower prices so they can compete in the market and to buy materials and tools to help the ones that work in other activities. Most of the members know the work of the similar solidarity groups like Agrocapital, so they know the responsibility and commitment required for the group to get the funds in order to produce a better quality job and get more income to improve their families quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Tuuituka (C) Group

texts.en:
M. is a 65-year-old married man. He has 10 children, ranging from 4 to 32. The oldest child is now a boda boda driver (a motorcycle used for public transport) and the youngest is still in the local government schools. M. also cares for his late brother's five children.

M. has been in the business of buying produce and re-selling it for 40 years. He says that people prefer his stand because he is trustworthy and dependable. He says that he has been around for a long time so people know him.

This loan cycle M. is requesting a loan of 2.5 million USH. With this amount Mukiiki will be able to buy a large amount of produce. He is also thinking of starting a new business, but he is not sure which one yet. M. hopes that in the future he will see all of his children finish school and be successful in their jobs!

loans.use: to buy a large stock of vegetables

loans.name: Milagros

texts.es: Milagros tiene 28 años, es casada, vive con su esposo George y su pequeño hijo de un año, que tiene el mismo nombre que su padre. Ella se dedica a la venta de ropa interior, su cuñada, la cual vive también en la misma casa, tiene una tienda, entonces Milagros aprovecha un espacio allí para vender sus prendas, lo cual es muy beneficioso porque puede estar cerca de su pequeño George, que requiere de muchos cuidados. Es por eso que este trabajo le cae muy bien, ya que lo realiza desde casa y al mismo tiempo genera ingresos para su hogar, muy aparte D. sueldo de su esposo. Por otro lado, su cuñada la está incitando para que se dedique a otra labor que le pueda arrojar mejores ingresos y como Milagros es conocida por ser muy creativa, la alientan para que ponga una piñatería o servicio de decoración con globos, o algún tipo de actividad que tenga que ver con la inventiva, por lo cual ella está animada de seguir estos consejos y prosperar mucho más. Este es su tercer préstamo con Microfinanzas PRISMA y siempre ha sido muy puntual en todos sus pagos. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de ropa interior para aumentar sus ventas y mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Milagros is 28 years old, married and lives with her husband, George, and her little one-year-old son who has the same name as his father. Her work is selling underwear. Her mother-in-law, who lives in the same house, has a store and so Milagros makes use of some space there to sell her items. This arrangement is very beneficial because it allows her to be near her little George who needs lots of care. That's why this work suits her well; because she can work at home and at the same time generate some income for the household, separate from her husband's salary. On the other hand, her mother-in-law is urging her to find some other work that would allow her to show greater income and, as Milagros is known to be very creative, they are encouraging her to start a piñata store or decorating with balloons, or some other activity where she could use her imagination. And so, Milagros is motivated to follow this advice so she can be more successful. This is her third loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA and she has always been very punctual with her payments. She will use the money she is requesting to buy a greater quantity of underwear in order to build up her sales and increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her merchandise.

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es:
La señora Maritza, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria”, vive en la Mza. E – Lt. 5, Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 36 años y es madre 02 hijos, 01 que todavía depende de ella.

Con su crédito de S/. 300.00, por iniciativa propia, inició su negocio con la venta de Anticuchos (carne a la parrilla) y nos cuenta que le va muy bien. En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio vendiendo sus asados y juanes (comida típica de la región), ubicada en la vereda de su casa, donde vende a los moradores de la comunidad, amigos y vecinos.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1000.00 que cancelará en 06 cuotas, lo invertirá ampliando e implementando su negocio, y comprará más mesas, sillas, vasos y ollas, e insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos.
Ella mayormente toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. Hoy se siente más independiente y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas y en los actos de su vida diaria.

Nos manifiesta su gran agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como Mujer y apoyar a otras mujeres que quieren emprender su negocio y salir adelante solas.
texts.en:
Maritza belongs to the “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria community bank. She lives at Mza. E – Lt. 5, in the Tarapoto district, in the San Martín department. She is 36, in a common law marriage, has 2 children, 1 is still dependent upon her. With a loan of 300 PEN and her own initiative, she started her business selling Anticuchos (grilled meat). It is going well for her. She still has the same business selling grilled meat and juanes (typical regional dish), located on the path to her house. She sells to community members, friends, and neighbors. With this loan for 1,000 PEN, which she will repay in 6 payments, she will carry out and expand her business. She will buy tables, chairs, glasses, pots and supplies for daily food preparation. Generally, she makes the decisions about the earnings from her business. She now feels more independent and responsible about making her payments and in her daily life. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a woman and for supporting other women who want to undertake their business and get ahead by themselves.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for food preparation.  To buy chairs and kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Lesli

texts.es:
La señora Lesli, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria”, vive en el Jr. Cajamarca Nº 160, Distrito de Tarapoto, departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 36 años y es madre 02 hijos, 01 que todavía depende de ella.

Con su crédito de S/. 300.00, por iniciativa propia, inició su negocio vendiendo comidas preparadas, nos cuenta que le va muy bien. En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio vendiendo sus alimentos, su negocio está ubicado en la vereda de su casa, donde vende a los moradores de la comunidad, amigos y vecinos.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1200.00 que cancelara a plazo de 06 meses, lo invertirá ampliando e implementando su negocio, y comprar más mesas, sillas, vasos y ollas, e insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos.
Ella mayormente toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. Hoy se siente más independiente y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas y en los actos de su vida diaria.

Nos manifiesta su gran agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como Mujer y apoyar a otras mujeres que quieren emprender su negocio y salir adelante solas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Leslie, belongs to the Communal Bank "Las Vencedores Villa Universitaria" and lives in Cajamarca Jr. No. 160, District of Tarapoto, San Martín. She lives with her partner, is 36 years and mother of 2 children, 1 still dependent on her. With her loan of S /. 300.00, taken on her own initiative, she started her business selling prepared foods and she tells us that it is doing very well. At present, she continues her business selling food, located on the pavement in front of her home, where she sells to residents of the community, friends and neighbors. With this loan of S /. 1200.00, she will invest to expand her business and buy more tables and chairs, cups and pots, and ingredients for the preparation of the daily food. She generally decides on how the profits of her business are used. She now feels more independent and responsible, for paying her bills and in other aspects of her daily life. She expressed great gratitude to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a women and support other women who want to start their own business and succeed on their own.

Translated from Spanish by Tim Hassett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for her food service businesss

loans.name: Babacar

texts.fr: Monsieur Babacar D. est un professeur de Mathématique et Science de la Vie et de la Terre au Collège Elémentaire Moyen de Ngueniene, un village de Sénégal.  Il a fait ce travail depuis 2004.  Avec ce prêt, il veut compléter son épargne pour acheter un terrain dans la localité ou il enseigne.  En 2008, il a reçu un crédit de 100,000 CFA ($200) qu’il a bien remboursé.  Monsieur D. et marié et il est âgé de 35 ans.  Il habite dans le quartier Cité Lamy de Thiès.
texts.en:
Mr. Babacar D. is a teacher of math and of earth and life sciences at the middle school of Ngueniene, a village in Sénégal. He has been doing this work since 2004. With this loan, he wants to round out his savings in order to buy a plot of land in the town where he teaches. In 2008, he received a loan of 100,000 francs CFA that he has repaid. Mr. D. is married and 35 years old, and he lives in the Cité Lamy district of Thiès.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy land

loans.name: Palmira

texts.es:
La señora Palmira, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria”, vive en el Jr. Elías Aguirre Nº 203, Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 39 años y es madre 01 hijo, que aun depende de ella.

Con su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 por iniciativa propia, emprendió su negocio de venta de menú (alimentos), ubicada en su misma casa.
En la actualidad, continúa con el mismo negocio, siendo sus principales clientes  los moradores de la comunidad, vecinos y amigos, con su carisma alegre y sonriente nos cuenta que sus ventas aumentaron y le esta yendo muy bien.
Con el préstamo de S/1.200.00 que cancelara a plazo de 06 meses, desea invertirlo comprando insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos como sacos de arroz, azúcar; aceites en paquetes, pollos en javas y también  mesas, sillas, vasos y ollas, para implementar su negocio y dar una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Nos cuenta que es ella quien toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio, se siente una Mujer fuerte, capaz e independiente y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas.
Palmira, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como Mujer y empresaria y ayudarle a cumplir sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Palmira is a member of the communal bank “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria (The Victorious of Villa University)”, and lives in Jr. Elias Aguirre No. 23, District of Tarapoto, Region of San Martin. She is single, 39 years old, and the mother of one son who depends on her.

With her first loan of 300 PEN, with her own initiative, she launched a business selling a menu of food located in her house. Today, she continues the same business, her main customers being the residents of the community, neighbors and friends. With her happy charisma and smile she tells us that her sales are increasing and going very well.

This loan of 1200 PEN, which she will pay on a 6 month plan, she would like to invest in the purchase of ingredients for the daily preparation of her plates, ingredients such as sacks of rice and sugar, oils in packets, chickens, and also tables, chairs, glasses, and cups in order to set up her business and give better attention to her customers.

She tells us that she is the one who makes decisions on the income of her business, and that she feels like a strong woman, capable, independent, and responsible with the payment of her loan. Palmira wants to show her appreciation to Manuela Ramos for permitting her to grow as a woman and businesswoman, and for helping her to fulfill her dreams and goals.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for the preparation of her menu of food.  To purchase chairs and utensils for the kitchen.

loans.name: Hidita

texts.es:
La señora Idita, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria”, vive en el Jr. Cajamarca Nº 136 – AA.HH. 10 de Agosto, Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 54 años y es madre de 06 hijos, 01 que aun depende de ella.

Con su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 por iniciativa propia emprendió su  negocio de Venta de plátanos y leña, con sus precios cómodos y a pedido de sus clientes, realiza sus ventas y nos cuenta que le va muy bien.
En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio ubicada en su propia casa, donde sus principales clientes son moradores de la comunidad, vecinos y amigos.
Con este préstamo de S/. 300.00 que cancelará a un  plazo de 04 meses, comprará  más productos para surtir su negocio como racimos de plátanos, tercios de leñas, sacos de yuca, para mantener contenta a su clientela.

Hoy se siente muy tranquila  y contenta del servicio que brinda a sus clientes. De Manuela Ramos, opina que es una institución que la ayudo a salir adelante.
texts.en:
Mrs. Idita is a member of the communal bank “Las Vencedoras de Villa Univesitaria (The Victorious of Villa University)”, and lives on 136 Cajamarca St., settlement of 10 de Agosto, District of Tarapoto, Region of San Martin. She has a partner, is 54 years old, and is the mother of six children, one of which depends on her.

With her first loan of 300 PEN she launched, of her own initiative, a business selling bananas and firewood. With her convenient prices and at the request of her customers she has made her sales and she tells us that it goes very well. Today she continues with the same business located in her house. Her main clients are the residents of the community, neighbors and friends.

This loan of 300 PEN, which she will pay on a four month plan, she will purchase more products to stock up her business such as bunches of bananas, bundles of firewood, and sacks of yucca in order to keep her customers happy. Today she feels very calm and happy with the service she provides to her customers. She feels that Manuala Ramos is an institution that has helped her to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bunches of bananas and firewood

loans.name: Maricela Ruth

texts.es:
La señora Maricela Ruth, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria”, vive en la Jr. Cenepa Mza. “D” Lt. 22 Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 22 años y no tiene hijos.
Con su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 emprendió su  propio negocio de Venta de Productos de Belleza, empezó vendiendo productos a pedido por catálogo de la línea EsiKa, CyZone, Avon, Natura, Oriflame; poco a poco fue haciéndose de su propio  stock.
Hoy continúa con su negocio ubicado en su misma casa, donde sus principales clientes son sus vecinos y amigos, nos cuenta que le va muy bien, ya que tiene clientes fijos, que hacen sus pedidos mensualmente.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 que cancelara a un  plazo de 06 meses, incrementará su negocio, ya que tiene un carácter especial con sus clientes, el dinero lo invertirá comprando más productos para su stock como perfumes, colonias, lociones y desodorantes para damas y caballeros; polvos, cremas y maquillajes de rostro.

De Manuela Ramos nos comenta que esta muy agradecida, y ayuda a las mujeres que no tienen una salida económica, a abrirse y progresar con la misma oportunidad que el varón. Es una mujer emprendedora y capaz de realizar y cumplir sus sueños.
texts.en:
Ms. Maricela Ruth is a member of the communal bank “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria.” She lives at Cenepa Mza. “D” Lt. 22, in the Tarapoto district, in the department of San Martín. She lives with her partner, is 22 years old, and has no children. With her first loan of 300.00 soles, she started her own business selling beauty products. She began selling lines of products from EsiKa, CyZone, Avon, Natura, Oriflame, ordered by catalog, and little by little she began acquiring her own stock. Today she continues with her business in her home since her main clients are her neighbors and friends. She tells us that it’s going very well because she has fixed clients who place orders monthly. With this loan of 1,000.00 soles, which she will pay off in 6 months, she will grow her business since it's dear to her clients. She will invest the money in purchasing products for her stock, like perfumes, colognes, lotions, deodorants for men and women, powders, creams, and make-up. She tells us that she is very grateful for Manuela Ramos. That it helps women who don’t have a source of income to open up, and to progress, with the same opportunities as men. She is an enterprising woman and capable of achieving her dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprara productos de belleza (perfumes, desodorantes, cremas.

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr: Adama D., 64 ans est veuve avec 08 enfants et 04 autres en charge. Elle est membre de banc villageois de Pout Diack depuis 4 ans Son activité  est la vente d’arachide, d’oignons et d’épices. Elle veut  renforcer son commerce et prendre en charge ses enfants Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Adama D., age 64, is a widow who has eight children plus four others to support. She has been a member of the village lending group of Pout Diack for four years. Her work involves selling peanuts, onions, and spices. She wants to bolster her commerce and care for her children. The loan she's requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell peanuts, onions, and spices.

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es:
La señora Maria Esther, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria”, vive en el Jr. Cenepa Mza. “D” Lt. 22 Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 42 años y es madre de 03 hijos, 02 que aun depende de ella.

Motivada por su energía emprendedora con el  primer crédito de S/. 300.00 inicio su  propio negocio de Venta de abarrotes y menú, dando alimentación diaria a sus clientes, donde ella siempre los atiende con su carisma y buen trato. En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio en un ambiente ubicado en su  misma casa, esta satisfecha con lo que hace.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 que cancelará a un  plazo de 06 meses, comprará  productos como sacos de arroz y azúcar; huevos en jabas, insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, gaseosas en paquetes, golosinas  y otros productos para mantener contenta a su clientela. También comprara insumos para preparar sus comidas a diario.

Se siente muy contenta, ya que sola supo salir adelante con sus hijos y gracias a Manuela Ramos que la apoyo bastante, cuenta con su negocio donde ella misma toma las decisiones de sus ingresos y egresos.
texts.en:
Ms. Maria Esther is a member of the communal bank “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria.” She lives at Jr. Cenepa Mza. “D” Lt. 22, the Tarapoto district, in the department of San Martín. She is single, 42 years old, and the mother of 3 children, 2 of whom are still dependents. Motivated by her enterprising spirit, she began her own business with the first loan of 300.00 soles. She began selling groceries and “menú” (plates of food), feeding her clients everyday, and treating them well with her charisma. She will continue with the same business which is located in her home. She is happy with what she is doing With this loan of 1,000.00 soles, which she will pay off in 6 months, she will buy products like: sacks of rice and sugar, crates of eggs, supplies for personal hygiene and for cleaning the house, sodas in packets, sweets, and other products to keep her clients happy. She will also buy supplies to prepare food on a daily basis. She is very happy since she has been able to get ahead on her own with her children and thanks Manuela Ramos who has supported her a lot. She can count on her business where it’s her making the decisions about her income and expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprara insumos para sus alimentos: arroz, azúcar, huevos.

loans.name: Mirsabeth

texts.es:
La señora Mirsabeth, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria”, vive en el Jr. Salaverry Nº 167, Distrito de Tarapoto, departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 28 años y es madre 05 hijos, que todavía depende de ella.

Con el préstamo de S/. 300.00, por iniciativa propia. Inicio su negocio con la venta de Anticuchos y nos cuenta que le va muy bien. En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio vendiendo comidas preparadas, asados y juanes, ubicada en la vereda de su casa, donde vende a los moradores de la comunidad, amigos y vecinos.
Con este préstamo de S/. 400.00 que cancelara a plazo de 04 meses, desea invertirlo, ampliando e implementando su negocio, y comprar más mesas, sillas, vasos y ollas, e insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos.
Ella mayormente toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. Hoy se siente más independiente y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas y en los actos de su vida diaria.

Mirsabeth, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer y apoyar a otras mujeres que quieren emprender su negocio.
texts.en:
Ms. Mirsabeth is a member of the communal bank, “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria.” She lives at Jr. Salaverry Nº 167, in the Tarapoto neighborhood, in the department of San Martín. She is single, 28 years old, and the mother of 5 children who are all still dependents. By her own initiative, she began her business selling beef hearts, with a loan of 300.00 soles. She tells us that it is going very well. At present, she will continue with the same business, selling prepared foods, roasted food, and “juanes” (similar to tamales). Her business is located on her home’s sidewalk, where she sells to her friends, neighbors, and the inhabitants of the community. She would like to invest in growing her business by buying more tables, chairs, glasses, pots, and supplies for the daily preparation of her food with this loan of 400.00 soles (which she will pay off in 4 months). She makes most of the decisions about the earnings from her business. Today she feels more independent and responsible about making her payments and in the everyday activities of her life Mirsabeth is grateful to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a businesswoman, and a woman, and for supporting other women who want to start their own businesses

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprara insumos para sus alimentos.  Compra de sillas, ollas y otros utencilios de cocina.

loans.name: Dony

texts.es:
La señora Dony, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria”, vive en el Jr. Cajamarca Nº 170 – AA.HH. 10 de Agosto, Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 28 años y es madre de 02 hijos, que aun dependen de ella.

Con su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 por iniciativa propia emprendió su  negocio de Venta de Abarrotes, que desde sus principios le dio buenos resultados, por la calidad de sus productos, sus precios cómodos y al gusto D. cliente.
En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio ubicada en su propia casa, donde sus principales clientes son moradores de la comunidad, vecinos y amigos.
Con este préstamo de S/. 300.00 que cancelará a un  plazo de 04 meses, comprará  más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en kilos, huevos en javas,  insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza D. hogar, gaseosas en paquetes, golosinas  y otros productos para mantener contenta a su clientela, 
Hoy se siente muy feliz de la labor y servicio que brinda y agradece a Manuela Ramos, por apoyar a personas como ella que quieren trabajar y salir adelante, espera que sigan así por mucho tiempo y ayuden a muchas familias y mujeres emprendedoras.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dony is a member of the communal bank “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria (The Victorious of Villa University)”, and lives at 170 Cajamarca St., settlement of 10 de Agosto, District of Tarapoto, Region of San Martin. She has a partner, is 28 years old, and the mother of two children who depend on her.

With her first loan of 300 PEN she launched, of her own initiative, a business selling groceries which has given her good results since the outset due to the quality of her products, her convenient prices, and because her customers are pleased. Today she continues with the same business located in her home. Her main customers are the residents of the community, neighbors and friends.

With this loan of 300 PEN, which will be paid on a four month plan, she will buy more products to stock her business such as rice and sugar in bulk, cartons of eggs, personal hygiene products, household cleaning products, cartons of sodas, candy, and other products to keep her clientele happy.

Today she feels very happy with the work and service she provides, and she appreciates Manuela Ramos for supporting people like her who want to work and get ahead. She hopes that they continue doing the same for a long time and that they help many families and enterprising women.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase groceries such as eggs, sugar, rice, and personal hygiene products.

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Marie S., 56 ans est  membre de banc villageois de Pout Diack depuis 6 ans et demi Son activité  est la vente de poisson et de légumes. Elle veut  renforcer son commerce. Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Marie S., age 56, has been a member of the village lending group of Pout Diack for six years. Her work involves selling fish and vegetables. She wants to bolster her business. The loan she's requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell fish and vegetables

loans.name: Cruz

texts.es: La señora Cruz, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Esperanza”, vive en el Jr. Iquitos Nº cdra. 04, Distrito de Juanjui, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 36 años y es madre 03 hijos, 02 que todavía depende de ella.Con su crédito de S/. 300.00, por iniciativa propia, inició su negocio vendiendo bebidas  y  nos cuenta que le va muy bien. En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio vendiendo sus menús en un local amplio, ubicada en la en su misma casa, donde vende a los moradores de la comunidad, amigos y vecinos. También se dedica al Alquiler de cuartos y mas adelante desea implementarlo mejor. Con este préstamo de S/. 3000.00 que cancelara a plazo de 06 meses, lo invertirá, ampliando e implementando su negocio, y comprará materiales como madera, calaminas, ladrillos y bolsas de cementos. Y parte del dinero también lo utilizara comprando paquetes de gaseosas de todos los sabores y tamaños.Ella mayormente toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. Hoy se siente más independiente y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas y en los actos de su vida diaria.Nos manifiesta su gran agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como Mujer y apoyar a otras mujeres que quieren emprender su negocio y salir adelante solas.
texts.en:
Ms. Cruz, belongs to the Banco Comunal "La Esperanza" and lives in Iquitos Jr. No. 4 block, Juanjui District, Department of San Martín. She lives with her partner, is 36 years old and mother of 3 children, 2 of whom still depend on her. With her loan of S /. 300.00, taken on her own initiative, she started a business selling drinks and tells us that it is doing very well. At present, she continues the business serving a menu in a large space, located right in her home, where she sells to residents of the community, friends and neighbors. She also rents rooms and later wants to improve on this business. With this loan of S /. 3000.00 to be repaid in 6 months, she will invest to expand her business and buy materials such as wood, calamine, bricks and cement bags. She will also use some of the money to buy packs of soda in many flavors and sizes. She generally make decisions regarding the profits of her business. She now feels more independent and responsible by paying her accounts and in the events of her daily life. She expresses her deep gratitude to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a woman and support other women who want to start their own business and succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Tim Hassett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials such as calamine, brick and cement.  And to Purchase softdrinks for sale,

loans.name: Maye

texts.fr: Maye F., 44 ans est membre de banc villageois de Pout Diack depuis 6 ans et demi Son activité est le commerce et l’embouche. Elle vend des pagnes, des draps de lit et engraisse des moutons pour les revendre. Elle veut  renforcer ses activités Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
