She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 380 Tala.  SPBD loans are Vaifanua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan for business improvements.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, file, knapsack sprayer, spade, axe, knives

loans.name: Katerina

texts.en: Katerina L., 38, is married with 3 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the villagers/public 3 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (approximately 145 USD).  SPBD loans are Katerina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase materials, a new sewing machine, threads, and needles.

loans.name: Tui

texts.en: Tui I., 30, is married with 3 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the villagers and public 4 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 380 Tala.  SPBD loans are Tui’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase knives, spade, knapsack sprayer, axe, chemicals etc.

loans.name: Salafune

texts.en: Salafune L., 48, is married with five  children. She has two years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public and villagers, five days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 370 tala (~$110 US).  SPBD loans are Salafune’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan for business improvement.

loans.use: To purchase wheelbarrow, spade, knives, file and fertilizer

loans.name: Litiana

texts.en: Litiana F., 29, is married with three children.  She has three years of experience in the barbeque business. She sells to the villagers and public, five days per week. She has had two previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$125 US).  SPBD loans are Litiana’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase foam plates, foil, boxes of chicken, sausages, mutton flaps, soy sauce, tomato sauce, garlic, onions, plastic bowls and potatoes.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for a barbeque business

loans.name: Faaiuga

texts.en: Faaiuga S., 44, is married with three children.  She has six years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the villagers and public, three days per week. She has not had any previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 tala (~$125 US).  SPBD loans are Faaiuga’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, spade, wheelbarrow, rake, water hose and vegetable seeds for tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbages, etc.

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina N., 54, is married with 5 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the food market business. She sells to the village people and public 3 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 420 Tala.  SPBD loans are Sina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She will use her loan for business improvement and home repairs.

loans.use: Purchase licence, laundry gears, tinned food, freezers, home repairs.

loans.name: Ioana

texts.en: Ioana S., 29, is married with 4 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the bakery business.  She sells to the villagers/public 3 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately 166 USD).  SPBD loans are Ioana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase bag of flour, sugar, cooking oil, whipping cream for icing and frying pan.

loans.name: Agasa

texts.en: Agasa S., 42, is married with 8 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public and villagers 4 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 410 Tala.  SPBD loans are Agasa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase knives, spade, knapsack sprayer, axe, chemicals etc.

loans.name: Lulu

texts.en: Lulu S., 37 is married with two children.  She has two years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the villagers and public, six days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 340 tala .  SPBD loans are Lulu’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sugar and flour, cooking oil, plastic bags and a big frying pan

loans.name: Karomat

texts.ru: Каромат-39 лет.Замужем,мать 5-х детей.Занимается откормом и купля-продажей скота.Муж Каромат имеет достоточно большой опыт в этой сфере и помогает ей.Каромат хочет купить на новый займ дойную корову и за счёт продажи молока и сметаны расширить свой товорооборот.Она кредитуется у нас больше 1 года и благодарна нашим кредиторам за помощь в осуществлении его планов. Всем своим соседям и знакомым,которые занимаются бизнесом и нуждаются в дополнительных денежных средствах она рекомендует кредитоваться в  нашей организации.
texts.en:
Karomat is a 39-year-old woman. She is married and the mother of five children. She raises, buys and sells cattle. Karomat's husband has considerable experience in this area and he assists her. With the new loan, Karomat wants to buy a milk cow and increase the variety of products she offers with the sale of milk and cream. She has been a client of MicroInvest for more than a year, and with the loan assistance has been able to realize her plans. She refers all her neighbors and acquaintances, who are in business and in need of funding, to MicroInvest for loan assistance.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and selling cattle

loans.name: Luteru

texts.en:
Luteru T., 26, is married with 2 children. She has 2 years of experience farming sugarcane. She sells her sugarcane to the schools in the village and public 5 days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 320 Tala.

She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are Luteru’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan for home improvements and business needs.

loans.use: Purchase materials for home and business improvements

loans.name: Valelia

texts.en:
Valelia S., 54, is married with 3 children. She has 6 years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the villagers and public 3 days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).

She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Valelia’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of the loan will be used to renovate her home.

loans.use: Purchase a new sewing machine and materials for renovating her house

loans.name: Fialauia

texts.en:
Fialauia M., 39, is married with 4 children. She has 2 years of experience in the Elei business. She sells retail to the village people 5 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 1570 Tala.

She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are Fialauia’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase materials for her business

loans.name: Laisene

texts.en: Laisene L., 47, is married with nine children.  She has two years of experience in the plantation and vegetable garden business. She sells to the villagers and public, four days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 900 Tala (~$285 US).  SPBD loans are Laisene’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for loans with the traditional banks. She will use her loan for home improvements and business needs.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals, a wheelbarrow, spray garden and weed killer

loans.name: Fuakoko

texts.en: Fuakoko T., 35, is married with six children.  She has had one year of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the village people and public, four days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 tala (~$125 US).  SPBD loans are Fuakoko’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan for home improvements and business needs.

loans.use: To purchase cement, roof, posts, paints, nails and brick

loans.name: Ergashali

texts.ru: Эргашали- мужчина 51 лет. Женат имеет одного ребенка. Он занимается откормом и купля-продажей скота. Эргашали после того как  приехал из заработок, с Российский Федерации в 2007 года занялся  откормом и продажей мелко рогатого кота. Он  имеет достаточный опыт в этой сфере. На полученный займ хочет купит  корм для своих овец. Таким образом,  ведет свои хозяйства и кормит свою семью. Ему также помогает сын и жена. Жена имеет опыт работы в сфере откорма скота.
texts.en:
Ergashali is 51 years old. He is married and has one child. He is works fattening, buying, and selling livestock. After Ergashali returned from working in the Russian Federation in 2007, he began fattening and selling small livestock. He has sufficient experience in this sphere. Once he receives the loan, he will buy fodder for his sheep. He makes a living and feeds his family in this way. His son and wife also help him. His wife has experience in fattening livestock.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: fattening and selling livestock

loans.name: Olive

texts.en:
Olive M., 38, is married with one child. She has one year of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public/villagers four days per week.

This is her first loan with SPBD, a Kiva partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 460 Tala. SPBD loans are Olive’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She seeks a loan to purchase a knapsack sprayer, chemicals, knives, an axe, a file and a ranging pole for business improvement.

loans.use: Purchase knapsack sprayer, chemicals, knives, axe, file, ranging pole

loans.name: Nuuuta

texts.en: Nuuuta F., 27, is married with one child.  She has one year of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the school and villagers, five days per week. She has not had any previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 180 tala (~$60 US).  SPBD loans are Nuuuta’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase bags of flour and sugar, baking soda, vegetable oil and cooking gas

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is 40 years old, married, and has three children aged 18, 10 and 9. She has been a bites (chapati) seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Shukrani group loan (Group code 2024). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. She works at her business from 8am to 10pm everyday.
 
Zainab is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more flour and cooking oil to expand her business. She is hoping that through the loan her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more flour and cooking oil to expand her business.

loans.name: Paulita

texts.en:
Paulita V., 47, is married with 4 children. She has 2 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the villagers and public 4 days per week. She has no previous loan with SPBD.

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~ 150 USD). SPBD loans are Paulita’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan for business improvement.

loans.use: To buy  knapsack, sprayer, chemicals, knives, axe, ranging pole.

loans.name: Usufono

texts.en:
Usufono S., 49, is married with 4 children. She has experience in the pancake business. She sells to the school and villagers 6 days per week. She has no previous loan with SPBD.

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 190 Tala (~63 USD). SPBD loans are Usufono’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan for her business.

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, baking soda, vegetable oil, cooking gas,

loans.name: Aigafou

texts.en: Aigafou V., 36, is married with four children.  She is just starting in the pancake business. She sells to the school and villagers, seven days per week. She has not had any previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 160 tala (~$50 US).  SPBD loans are Aigafou’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase bags of flour and sugar, baking soda, vegetable oil, oven and frying pan

loans.name: Stahil Salama Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 26 years old, married, and has a two-year-old child. She has been a clothes seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Stahil Salama Group loan (Group code 2026). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60. She works hard at her business everyday. 

Fatma requests her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more clothes for resale to improve her business. She hopes that through the loan her profit will increase, and she will be able to grow her business. 

She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Chakacha, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale to expand her business.

loans.name: Makerita

texts.en:
Makerita L., 31, is married with one child. She has one year of experience in the handicrafts business. She sells retail and to the hotels four days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (approximately $100).

She has no previous loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are Makerita’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan for business improvement.

loans.use: To purchase paints, cover papers, knives, needles,  etc.

loans.name: Abias Kemuel

texts.es: Abias Kemuel E., vive en Ahuachapán junto con su madre y hermanas. Kemuel es el hombre de la casa, es él, el único apoyo económico para su madre y hermanas que aun están en colegio; el negocio de Kemuel es una tienda con productos de consumo, que se encuentra ubicado en el mercado. Kemuel solicita un crédito ya que tiene una buena demanda en su tienda, por lo cual desea surtirla.
texts.en:
Abias Kemuel E. lives in Ahuachapán together with his mother and sisters. Kemuel is the man of the house and is the only support for his mother and sisters who are still in school. Kemuel's business is a store with basic need items. It is located in a marketplace. Kemuel is asking for a loan since he has good sales in his store which is why he desires to stock it with more merchandise.

(Translated by Ashlee of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock his store with more merchandise.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is 30 years old, married, and has three children aged 12, 7 and 4. Asha has been a fish seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Tuwe wa kwel group loan (Group code 2048). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60. She works hard at her business everyday. 

She requests her third loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more fish for resale. She hopes that through the loan her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish for resale to expand her business

loans.name: Efren

texts.en:
Efren Laborto is 40 years old and is blessed with one child. He was elected as the barangay councilor in his village. He is a pig grower and wants to expand his pig-raising business to support his family well. To supplement his income, he also grows rice. He has been tilling his rice farm (more than 1 hectare in size) that he inherited from his parents. Raising pigs and growing rice are his only source of income. 

He now requests a loan of PHP 6,000 from CEVI to buy pig feed and fertilizers. Efren has been a CEVI client since a long time. He receives not only loans but also trainings and insurance coverage from CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and fertilizers

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita P. owns a small hectare (2 acre) farm in their village. She grows rice which she sells to provide additional income for her family. She also saves some of her harvest for her family’s consumption. Her husband is also a farmer and they have been tilling the land together for 20 years already. She is 42 years old and has five children.

She is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and other farm necessities. The loan will help her family a lot by increasing their yield.


CEVI has reached out to thousands of people, helping them to start and have their own business. It provides not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals for her farm

loans.name: Jene's Group

texts.en:
N. Jene is the leader of Atakola group in Jinja. She owns a pharmacy business since past 20 years. She is married with 5 children, all of whom attend school. She also looks after her extended family, including in laws, cousins and nieces. This is her third loan with the group, and she intends to buy more stock of medicines for her pharmacy. 

Jene also dreams of opening up branches of her shop which will be run by her other employees under her direct supervision. Due to the loans that she has been receiving in the past year-and-a-half, her medicine stock has increased. With this new loan too, Jene is going to buy more tablets, syringes, needles, anti malarial syrups and other drugs for her customers.

loans.use: Buying more stocks of medicines for her pharmacy

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is 35 years old, married, and has three children aged 16, 10 and 4. She also looks after one additional dependent. Mwanahawa has been a perfumes and khanga seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. She belongs to Mapatano group loan (Group code 2070). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $95. She works at her business for 12 hours daily.
 
She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more perfumes and khanga for sale to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase, and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

loans.use: To buy more perfumes and khanga for sale to improve her business

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha has owned a small charcoal and firewood store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 20 years. She works at her business for eight hours every day and currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. She belongs to Bora utu group loan (Group code 2021).

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood to add her current stock, so as to expand her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Asha is 48 years old, married, and has five children: ages 31, 27, 24, 20 and 18.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood to sell

loans.name: Jean

texts.en: Mrs. Jean A., a 23-year-old mother of one, is married to Mr. Marven A., a motorcycle driver earning about 5,000php a month.  Jean supports her husband through her business of renting boats for quarrying and she is also a barangay health worker. She is requesting a loan of 6,000php for the maintenance and labor costs of her business. Jean hopes to be more productive and have a healthy living.

loans.use: For the maintenace of her business renting boats for quarrying.

loans.name: Latifa

texts.en:
Latifa has been a tailor and seller of charcoal and bites in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 10 years. She belongs to A'Mola group loan (Group code 2039) and currently earns an average monthly profit of $95 working daily at her business. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal, wheat flour and cooking oil for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Latifa is 50 years old, widowed, and has six children ranging in age from 30 to 18.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal, wheat flour, cooking oil and other items for her business.

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu, a cosmetics and clothes seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar, belongs to Nia safi group loan (Group code 2020) and currently earns an average monthly profit of $50 working daily at her business. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more cosmetics and khanga for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Tatu is 36 years old, married, and has four children: ages 20, 18, 15 and 12. She also cares for one additional dependent.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and khanga for her business.

loans.name: Grace's Group

texts.en: Grace M., a mother of four caring for five dependents, is the leader of Atakola group in Jinja. She has a bar business where she sells cold drinks including sodas, mineral water, wines, beers and local brew. This will be Grace’s third loan with Pearl Microfinance, but she has received loans before from Finca Uganda. Grace needs to buy a greater volume of drinks for her bar in order to meet growing customer demand. She is grateful for her loans and the group she is in since they are cooperative and advise each other on business matters.

loans.use: To purchase more cold drinks such as sodas and beers for her bar.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta D. is a 52 year old widow blessed with seven children. Only one of them is working. Their source of income comes from making pottery.

She is a good member of Paglaum Coop since she joined last year. Her business started with experience gained from her neighbours. And, to start the business, she obtained a loan in the amount of Php 4,000 from Paglaum Cooperative. Since then, the business is still going and now she already needs a bigger amount of capital for her to buy more clay and to pay labor and transportation expenses. She has obtained a loan amount of Php 15,000 to do this.

Her hope is to have a better living for her family and that her business will have more progress.

loans.use: To buy clay and pay for transportation and labor costs

loans.name: Monica's Group

texts.en: Monica B., the married mother of three who also cares for one orphan, is the representative of Atakola group in Jinja.  Monica has a grocery store that operates on a modest scale. When she joined her lending group, she had had the business for only one year, but since then has used her loans to increase the stock. As a result, she has been able to pay school fees for her children with the help of her husband as well as increase her business’s capital. She is requesting a new loan to help with restocking her shop with more products.

loans.use: Restocking her shop with more products.

loans.name: Subira In Mpaka Group

texts.en:
Halima has owned a small charcoal store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60. She works at her business for eight hours every day.

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal for resale and expand her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money for future use, improve her home and pay school fees for her children.

Halima is 45 years old, widowed, and has four children: ages 31, 30, 25 and 20. She also cares for one additional dependent.

Halima will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mwanahaji and Dalila. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for resale and expand her business

loans.name: Winona

texts.en:
M. Winona is a 62 year old widow with three children. Two of them are already working. She is a businesswoman and a very hardworking mother.

She is a good and active member of Paglaum since she joined. She has no record of default payment or arriving late for their meetings.

Her business started in 1999 with a capitalization of only 2,000 Php. During the harvest period she delivers her pigs to her customers in the meat shop in the neighboring town.

Now she needs more capital to buy more pigs, vitamins and pig-feed and to maintain her business. Her business helps her so much with the needs of her family, especially since she is already a widow.

loans.use: To buy more pigs, pig-feed and vitamins

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma has owned a small shop (general store) in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. Every day she works at her business for eight hours.

Fatma belongs to Tuwe wakweli group loan. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to add to her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Fatma is 46 years old, married, and has four children: ages 23, 21, 19 and 10.

loans.use: To buy more items to add to her current stock

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn O. is a 41 year old woman, married to Paulino O., a laborer. The couple is blessed with four children and presently live in the town of Plaridel, Misamis Occidental.

Evelyn is a new member of Paglaum Cooperative. She needs the amount of 10,000 Php to buy additional stock for her sari-sari (general) store. She will religiously pay her obligation on time.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of groceries for her store

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine J. is renting a small parcel of land to farm rice. She is 55-years old and already a widow. She would like to grow her business and buy her own rice field someday. Now, she is worrying about how she will be able to stretch her limited income. She has decided to grow vegetables in her backyard for additional income.

She is asking for a loan of 15,000 PHP from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm necessities. The loan will help her family a lot to increase the harvest.

CEVI is a non-profit organization set up to respond to the needs of small entrepreneurs. It helps provide not just loans, but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm necessities

loans.name: Marigee

texts.en:
Marigee O., 30, is from Tudela,Misamis Occidental. She is single and presently lives with her parents. She is a new member of Paglaum MPC under micro-finance program,who joined in November. She wants to help her parents with their daily necessities. Within the period of her membership she demonstrated excellent performance in terms of loan repayments.

She loaned the amount of Php10,000.00 to purchase stock for her sari-sari (variety) store, where you can buy assorted goods. She hopes to enrich their way of life and expand the business.

loans.use: Additional capital for sari-sari store

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: ADEBASSI est une femme très dynamique, elle est divorcée de son mari  et  pour subvenir à ses besoins elle a entamé la vente de produits d’alimentation générale, elle s’approvisionne le plus souvent au grand marché de Lomé et au marché local de hedrzanawoè. Son stock étant épuisé, elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 1 sac de riz, 4 sacs de charbons, 7 bidons d’huile et d’autres produits
texts.en:
ADEBASSI is a very energetic woman. She is divorced, and to support herself, she has begun to sell groceries. She supplies herself most often at the grand market of Lomé and at the local market of Hedrzanawoè. Her stock being exhausted, she's requesting her first loan from WAGES to buy a sack of rice, four sacks of charcoal, seven drums of oil, and other goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, oil, charcoal, and various other goods

loans.name: Jitahidi Group

texts.en:
Mtumwa has been a fish and bread seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. She currently earns a minimal monthly profit. Every day, she works at her business for eight hours.

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania, a Kiva partner, so that she can buy more fish and bread for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use, improve her home and pay school fees for her children.

Mtumwa is 40 years old, married and has eight children ranging in age from age 9 to 25. She also cares for one additional dependent.

She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Hawa, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more fish and bread for resale

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosalie D. is 32 years old and a resident of Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is blessed with one child who is in grade four. Her husband is a part-time driver and at the same time lends a hand in farming, specifically in corn production which is their primary activity.

They own a little parcel of land. It began as a back-yard gardening project with onions planted on it and eventually led to corn production for consumption and for business too.

Rosalie has been a member of Paglaum MPC since June 2008. She is now applying for Php 6,000 intended to buy farm fertilizers and pesticides. She dreams that maybe someday she will be the supplier of corn in the market.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides for her farm

loans.name: Mercie

texts.en:
Business-minded Mercie U. is 23 years old, single and lives at Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She runs a sari-sari (general) store.

At her age she is zealous to be in business, believing that it is a great help to resolve poverty, to help the family and to fulfill one’s dream. The said sari-sari store is located adjacent to a government school. Her regular customers are students, teachers, friends and neighbors.

She is a new member of Paglaum MPC since March 2009. She is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy additional goods for her sari-sari store. She's planning, and looking forward to, finishing in college so that she can have a brighter future and is able to help her family.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza has been a clothes and plates seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $30. Every day she works at her business for eight hours.

She belongs to Tumejidhatiti group loan (Group code 2091). She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and plates to add to her current stock. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Aziza is 28 years old, married, and has a six-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and plates to add to her current stock

loans.name: Batnasan

texts.en:
Batnasan B. lives with his wife and four teenage children in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. All four children are high-school students.

Batnasan has a small business selling textiles. He started the textile business in 2000 after his family moved from Uvs, a far western province, to Ulaanbaatar. He purchases textiles from Ereen, a Chinese border town where many products are imported from, and sells them to individual small retailers at the local markets in Ulaanbaatar.

In order to diversify his textile selection, he also imports from South Korea. He buys Korean textiles in bulk at wholesale prices and resells them. In the future, he would like to have his own textile shop where he will be able to sell all sorts of textiles and not go through a middleman. Batnasan requests a loan to purchase more textiles to increase his business inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more textiles to increase his business inventory

loans.name: Buyan-Ulziy

texts.en:
Buyan-Ulziy S. lives with his wife, his son and his daughter-in-law in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His son is a college student. Buyan-Ulzii's family moved to Ulaanbaatar from the countryside three years ago.

As soon as Buyan-Ulziy came to Ulaanbaatar, he started a small business with his wife in construction. Buyan-Ulziy and his wife have years of experience in construction. They mostly work on the interior design of new construction projects on a contract basis. In the future, he would like to expand his business by hiring more employees and creating a full team of construction workers. Buyan-Ulziy requests a loan to purchase raw materials used in his construction business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials used in his construction business

loans.name: Janlav

texts.en:
B. Janlav lives with her husband and four teenage children in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The oldest son is a university student and the rest of the children are high-school students.

Bayambasuren has a small business sewing children’s clothing. She is a trained seamstress and has been making children clothes, including school uniforms, since 1997. The whole family contributes to B.'s business in some way. Her two daughters help her make new school uniforms when they have many client requests. When school starts in the fall, there is usually a very high demand for school uniforms. During these times, she hires two more temporary seamstresses.

For now, she is working out of one of bedrooms at her house, in order to avoid paying rent. In the future, she hopes to have a working place for her business. She requests a loan to purchase raw materials such as textiles for her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials such as textiles for her business

loans.name: Rabia

texts.en:
Rabia has owned a small charcoal store and has been a juice seller the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. She belongs to the Subira ina mpaka group loan (Group code 2062). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $25. Every day she works at her business for eight hours.

She is requesting her second loan from Kiva partner BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and juice for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Rabia is 26 years old, married and has two children, ages 7 and 4.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and juice for her business

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en:
M. Betty, together with her group members, has successfully completed the repayment of her loan and she is now applying for another one.

Her matooke-selling business is doing well and this is possible because the yields of the matooke (green bananas) from her farm are of high quality, hence being favored by her customers. Also, the pricing is good since the bananas are not so much in plentiful supply. Betty also buys from other farmers that have quality yields in the far away villages and this enables her to have much more to sell to her ever-increasing number of customers.

Betty needs a new loan to help with clearing another piece of land where she can put in fresh cultivations and to buy more bunches of matooke for sale.

loans.use: To pay for manpower on her farm and to buy more bananas to sell

loans.name: Huuhee

texts.en:
Huuhee E. is married and has one daughter. His wife, Dolgormaa, stays at home to take care of their infant.

From 2000 to 2008, Huuhee helped his parents’ business making home furniture to sell at the local market. In 2008, he married and moved away to start making and selling furniture, including beds, tables and chairs, independently.

Huuhee's family rents a house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. With his profits, Huuhee plans to buy a plot of land and build his own house. He is a peaceful and responsible person who is requesting a loan to buy raw materials such as wood and glue for his business.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for his furniture making business.

loans.name: Richard's Group

texts.en:
Richard K. represents the Tumwesige group in Lugazi. He is a very hard-working man with a motorcycle business that he has owned for two years. He owns one motorcycle that he drives himself but plans to buy two more and employ others to drive them. 

Thanks to the loans he has received, he has been able to buy a plot of land and other household items, which he otherwise could not have owned. He needs a loan to help repair his motorcycle so that he can bring in more money.

loans.use: Repairing his motorcycle in order to earn more money.

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr: Madame Antoinette T. est une commerçante Sénégalaise qui sollicite un crédit pour renforcer son entreprise de commerce.  Avec ce crédit elle va acheter sept rouleaux de bassins, de la teinture, et de la couture pour les revendre a Thiès, Sénégal, la ville ou elle habite.  Elle va aussi payer le transport pour acheter la marchandise.  Elle a déjà reçu trois crédits auprès de l’IMCEC depuis 2004, et elle a tout bien remboursé.  Madame T. travaille aussi à la pharmacie, et elle a des revenus supplémentaires avec son entreprise.  Elle est âgée de 37 ans et elle est mariée.  Elle va utiliser les revenus de son entreprise pour aider dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
Ms. Antoinette T. is a Senegalese merchant who is requesting a loan to bolster her commercial enterprise. With this loan, she's going to buy seven rolls of damask fabrics, dyes, and sewing supplies to resell in Thiès, Senegal, the city in which she lives. She's also going to pay for the transportation for buying her merchandise. She has had three loans from IMCEC since 2004, and she repaid them all. Ms. T. also works at the pharmacy, and she has additional revenues from her enterprise. She is 37 years old and married. She's going to use her revenues to help cover day-to-day expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth, dyes, and sewing supplies

loans.name: Jargalsayhan

texts.en:
Jargalsayhan L. is 36, married and the father of two daughters. Both of his daughters attend a local high school. His family lives in a condominium that he owns in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife is currently unemployed and stays home.

In 2008, together with his brothers, Jargalsayhan launched a car care center. His daily tasks include checking and replacing engine oil, filters and engine coolant. To expand his business, he plans to start repairing car tires. He employs three full-time paid staff. In the future, he plans to expand, in order to make his car care center larger and more professional.

Jargalsayhan is a very open-minded and loyal person. He is requesting a loan to buy tire repair equipment and new tires.

loans.use: To buy tire repair equipment and new tires.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr: Madame Mariama D. une commerçante Sénégalaise qui sollicite un crédit pour renforcer son entreprise agricultural qu’elle fait chez elle.  Elle a commencé de faire ce travail depuis des années.  Avec ce crédit elle va acheter 100 poussins, 7 sacs alimentaires, et des vaccines.  En plus, elle vend des tissus, le thioub (un type de tissu Sénégalais), sac à mains, et chaussures.  Elle a déjà reçu trois crédits auprès de l’IMCEC depuis 2006, et elle a tout bien remboursé.  Elle est âgée de 46 ans et elle est mariée.  Elle va utiliser les revenus de son entreprise pour régler les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
Ms. Mariama D. is a Senegalese merchant who is requesting a loan to bolster her agricultural enterprise she has at home. She started doing this work a few years ago. With this loan, she's going to buy 100 chicks, seven sacks of feed, and some vaccines. In addition, she sells fabrics: thioub (a type of Senegalese cloth), handbags, and shoes. She has had three loans from IMCEC since 2006, and she repaid them all. She is 46 years old and married. She will use the revenues from her enterprise to cover day-to-day expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chicks, sacks of feed, and vaccines

loans.name: Wastra Group

texts.en:
For the last two years, Maryam M. has made a living selling snacks and porridge in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Wastara loan group, and currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. She works at her business for 12 hours a day. 

Maryam is requesting a new loan, her third, from BRAC Tanzania to buy more flour and cooking oil, which she will use to make items to sell to her customers. She hopes that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to expand her business.  

Maryam M. is 25 years old, married and has three children, ages 7, 4 and 2.  She will share this loan with her fellow group member, Maryam O. S., who makes a living selling firewood in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi ont en moyenne 50 ans, 5 enfants et vivent majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygames. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage dans le quartier Bamanan kin  de Markala quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali
Elles font essentiellement le commerce de pagnes wax, de bois de chauffe, des condiments alimentaires, de céréales, la production de beurre de karité etc. Après avoir vu des cas de réussite d’autres femmes de Markala (4ème région administrative du Mali) qui ont pu mener des activités génératrices de revenus à travers Soro Yiriwaso, les membres du groupe s’organisèrent davantage pour intégrer le programme crédit, avec qui elles sont à leur 4ème prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 25 sacs de mil, 10 sacs de haricot, 2500 kg d’oignon et  35 sacs de fakoye à moudre (plante sauvage utilisée dans la sauce surtout au nord du Mali). Elles s’approvisionnent à la foire hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou auprès des grossistes et des producteurs. Les produits sont revendus en détail, au comptant et à crédit au marché de Kirango à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et pour la prise en charge des fournitures scolaires des enfants.
 Elles ont pour ambition de se procurer de matériels agricoles (charrues et boeufs de labour).
texts.en:
The women of the group Benkadi average 50 years of age and 5 children each. They live mainly in large polygamous families, and they know one another through community ties in the Bamanan Kin district of Markala (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They essentially do commerce in Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), firewood, condiments, grains, the making of shea nut butter, etc.

After having seen success cases of other Markala women who were able to run businesses and earn revenues through Soro Yiriwaso, the group members got organized more, so as to join the loan program. They are now on their fourth solidarity loan, which will be used to buy: 25 sacks of millet, 10 sacks of beans, 2,500 kg of of onions, and 25 sacks of fakoye (a wild plant used in making sauces, especially in northern Mali). Supplies are gotten at the weekly fairs of Diamarabougou from wholesalers and producers. The goods are sold retail, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of men and women at the Kirango marketplace.

The group members each hope to realize an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be used to make loan interest payments and to cover the cost of school supplies for the children. Their ambition is to acquire agricultural equipment (carts and oxen).

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain and condiments

loans.name: Terbish

texts.en:
Terbish D. lives with her husband and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son is 23 years old and attends a local university. Her husband is ill and stays at home. Terbish runs a small retail business selling women's apparel. She buys low-cost yet decent women’s clothing in Ereen, a Chinese border town where many products are imported, and sells them at the stall that she rents in the Narantuul market, the largest open market in Ulaanbaatar. 

For the last two years, she has been traveling to Ereen, China once a month to buy clothes. When she leaves for Ereen, her cousin helps at the stall. In the future, she hopes to have her own shop where she will be able to sell her products, instead of renting a stall. She is applying for this loan to buy more women's clothing in China.

loans.use: to buy more women's clothing to sell to her customers

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: Monsieur Mamadou S. sollicite son deuxième crédit auprès de l’IMCEC et Kiva pour régler ses besoins sociaux de santé.  Il a 40 ans et il habite à Thiès, une ville 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.  Il a une épargne chez l’IMCEC et il a bien remboursé le premier crédit.  Monsieur S. est célibataire et il travail comme agent de Program Renforcement Nutritionnel, un program social de Christian Children’s Fund qui aide les enfants pauvres a Thiès.  Ses amis l’appellent « Vieux S. ».
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou S. is requesting his second loan from IMCEC and Kiva to cover his health needs. He is 40 years old and lives in Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Sénégal. He has a savings account with IMCEC, and he has repaid his first loan. Mr. S. is unmarried and works as a representative of Program Renforcement Nutritionnel, a social program of the Christian Children’s Fund, which helps poor children in Thiès. His friends call him "Old S.".

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To cover his health requirements

loans.name: Dembagnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dembagnouman est composé d‘une veuve et de quatre femmes mariées. Majoritairement monogames ayant en  moyenne 36 ans et 3 enfants,  elles vivent toutes dans des grandes familles traditionnelles  dans le quartier Bamanan kin de Kirango Markala (4ème Région administrative du Mali. 
Elles excellent dans le commerce des céréales. En plus des céréales, elles vendent  du bois de chauffe pendant  l’hivernage.
Après avoir correctement remboursé les deux premiers prêts solidaires, ce groupe est à son 3ème prêt  qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 16 sacs d’arachide en gousse qui sont décortiqués et triés dont une partie est transformée en pâte d’arachide pour  être  vendue, 3 sacs de riz et 5 sacs de mil. Elles  s’approvisionnent en arachide  et en mil à Boussin et au marché hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou Markala, en riz à Dougabougou et Siribala. Elles vendent généralement au comptant et à crédit à domicile, au marché quotidien  de Kirango et au marché hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32.000FCFA  qui sera utilisé dans le remboursement du prêt, la prise en charge de certaines dépenses familiales (savon, pétrole et habillements), l’épargne et l’augmentation du fonds de commerce. 
Elles ont pour ambitions  d’avoir une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The group Dembagnouman is composed of a widow and four married women. Mainly monogamous and averaging 36 years of age and 3 children each, they all live in large traditional families in the Bamanan Kin district of Kirango Markala (fourth administrative region of Mali). They do commerce in grains. In addition to grains, they sell firewood during the off-season.

After having correctly repaid the first two solidarity loans, this group is on its third loan, which will be used to buy: 16 sacks of peanuts (to be shelled and sorted, a portion of which will be made into peanut butter for sale); 2 sacks of rice; and 5 sacks of millet. Supplies of peanuts and millet are gotten in Boussin and at the weekly market of Diamarabougou Markala; the rice, in Dougabougou and Siribala. The goods are generally sold out of the house, cash or credit accepted, and also at the daily market of Kirango, and at the weekly market of Diamarabougou.

The group members envision realizing an average monthly profit of 32,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan, to cover certain family expenses (soap, kerosene, and clothing), to put into savings, and to boost capital. Their ambition is to have a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia makes a living selling juice in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to the Jambo nia loan group, and currently earns an average monthly profit of $40. She works for 12 hours a day.

Safia is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania, which she will use to buy sugar and mangos, make more juice and increase her income. She hopes that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to expand her business.  

Safia is 35  years old, married, and has three children.

loans.use: To buy sugar and mangoes to use to make juice.

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djekafo ont en  moyenne 40 ans. Le groupe est composé  de 6 femmes mariées (dont 5 monogames) qui vivent toutes dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 6 enfants dans le quartier Bamanan kin de Kirango Markala (4ème Région administrative de Ségou).
Le besoin d’augmenter leurs fonds  de commerce  amena le groupe à s’organiser et adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son 4ème prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé les trois premiers prêts.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter,  8 sacs de mil, 7 corbeilles de poisson. Elles s’approvisionnent en mil au marché hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou, en poisson au bord du fleuve Niger à Kirango dont une partie est séchée avant sa vente. Elles effectuent leur vente  à domicile, au marché journalier de Kirango Markala et quelques fois au marché hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou Markala, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles  comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 23.500FCFA par mois  qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour la prise en charge des besoins de la famille (soins de santé des enfants, nourritures, frais scolaires etc.) Elles ont pour ambition d’acheter du matériel agricole (notamment des bœufs de labour, des charrues) afin d’assurer l’autosuffisance alimentaire et de pérenniser leurs activités commerciales.
texts.en:
The members of the group Djekafo have an average age of 40. The group is composed of six married women (including five monogamous) who all live in large traditional families with an average of six children in the Bamanan Kin district of Kirango Markala (fourth administrative region of Ségou).

The need to augment their capital has lead the group members to organize themselves and to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are now on their fourth solidarity loan, after having repaid the first three loans.

This loan will be used to buy 8 sacks of millet and 7 baskets of fish. Supplies of millet are gotten at the weekly market of Diamarabougou. The fish is gotten on the banks of the Niger River in Kirango, and a portion of the fish will be dried and then sold. Sales are made to customers composed of men and women, at the house, at the daily market of Kirango Markala, and sometimes at the weekly market of Diamarabougou Markala, cash or credit accepted.

The group members each plan to realize an average profit of 23,500 francs CFA each month. The profits will be used essentially to meet family needs (health care for the children, food, school fees, etc.). Their ambition is to buy agricultural supplies (notably oxen and carts) in order to ensure self-sufficiency in food and to continue their commercial businesses indefinitely.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy millet and fish

loans.name: Tuwe Wa Kweli Group

texts.en:
Mwantatu makes a living selling charcoal and firewood in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Tuwe wa kweli loan group, and currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. She works at her trade for 12 hours a day.  

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania, which she will use to buy more charcoal and firewood to sell to her customers. She is hoping that this loan will allow her to increase her profits and grow her business.

Mwantatu is 30 years old, widowed and a three-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her loan group members, Salma and Kibibi, each of whom runs a small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma E. makes a living selling fish. Every day, she goes to the nearby village to sell fish to her regular customers. She is 42 years old, married and has three children. She dreams that someday, she will have a new house for her family.

She has applied for a loan to buy more fish to sell. Gemma has many regular customers, and wants to be able to accommodate all of their needs.

She has been a CEVI client for a long time, and gets training and insurance from us as well as loans.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou D. est un homme marié de 34 ans qui est père de 2 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans la  quartier Hérémakono Nord de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école, il a fait le berger pendant 10 ans derrière le bétail familiale. Dans le souci de subvenir à ses propres besoins, il décida de venir à Bougouni chez son frère pour apprendre le commerce notamment la vente  dans une boutique d’articles divers.
Après trois années exercice  de cette activité auprès de son frère, Seydou maitrise les tenants et aboutissants du commerce général et évolue actuellement en solo.
En vu de renforcer  son fonds de commerce, Monsieur Seydou D. décida de rejoindre le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son premier prêt individuel avec Soro Yiriwaso.
 Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, divers articles pour sa boutique.  Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali.). Sa clientèle est composée de la population locale.
 Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Seydou D. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice il envisage agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou D., age 34, is a married man and the father of two. He lives with his wife and children in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having attended school, he worked as a shepherd for ten year with the family livestock. Concerned about supporting himself, he decided to come to Bougouni where his brother lives to learn commerce, particularly selling various goods in a shop. After three years working in this business with his brother, he is mastering all the ins and outs of general commerce and is currently improving on his own.

To bolster his capital, Seydou decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He is on his first individual loan with Soro Yiriwaso. He intends to use this loan to buy various merchandise for his shop. He supplies himself in Bamako (capital of Mali). His customers are composed of local people. With this loan, he plans to realize a monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that he envisions using to expand his shop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods for his shop

loans.name: Seynabou

texts.fr: Madame Seynabou L. exerce le commerce depuis des années.  Avant, elle vendait des colas, un grain que les Sénégalais mangent pour avoir plus d’énergie.  Maintenant, elle est « Diawbe », c'est-à-dire elle fait la navette pour acheter les produits locaux dans le sud de Sénégal pour les vendre à Thiès, une ville située 70 kilomètres de Dakar.  Avec ce premier crédit qu’elle a sollicité auprès de l’IMCEC et Kiva, elle va acheter de l’huile de palme, de la patte d’arachides, et des balaies.  Elle va aussi payer le transport pour acheter la marchandise.  Elle a 56 ans et elle est mariée, et avec les revenus de son entreprise elle va aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
Ms. Seynabou L. has been working in commerce for some years. Before, she used to sell kolas, a nut that the Senegalese eat for more energy. Now, she is a "Diawbe", that is to say, she shuttles back and forth, buying local goods in southern Senegal to sell them in Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar.

With this first loan, she's going to buy palm oil, peanut butter, and brooms. She's also going to pay for the transportation for buying the merchandise. She is 56 years old and married, and with the revenues from her enterprise, she'll help her husband with day-to-day expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy palm oil, peanut butter, and brooms

loans.name: Saye

texts.fr: Saye S., 57 ans est mariée avec 08 enfants en charge. Elle est membre de banc villageois de Pout Diack depuis 6 ans et demi. Son activité  consiste à acheter et revendre du charbon de bois et du pain. Elle compte  renforcer son commerce  pour augmenter ses revenus Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Saye S., age 57, is married and has eight children to support. She has been a member of the village lending group of Pout Diack for six and a half years. Her business involves buying and reselling charcoal and bread. She intends to bolster her business in order to augment her revenues. The loan she's requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in charcoal and bread

loans.name: Mbougane

texts.fr: Madame Mbougane D. a commencé à faire le commerce depuis l’âgé très jeune.  Son activité consiste à vendre du thieré (du couscous en mil) et le fonde.  Le fonde est une bouilli (un pudding) qui est fait avec de la farine de mais pilé et du lait caillé que les Sénégalais mangent pour le petit déjeuner.  Avec ce crédit, elle va acheter du mil et du mais pour préparer ses produits.  Madame D. est âgée de 52 ans.  Elle habite à Thiès avec son mari, et avec les revenus de son entreprise elle paye les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Ms. Mbougane D. started in commerce at a very young age. Her work involves selling thieré (made of couscous and millet) and fonde, which is a pudding that is made with pounded cornmeal and curdled milk that the Senegalese eat for breakfast. With this loan, she's going to buy some millet and corn to make these products. Ms. D. is 52 years old. She lives in Thiès with her husband. With the revenues from her enterprise, she covers the expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy millet and corn

loans.name: Ulambayar

texts.en:
Ulambayar E. lives with his wife and two children in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His oldest son is a second-grader at a local high school and the youngest son goes to a local kindergarten.

Ulambayar would like to start a small business making blocks and bricks for construction. Three years ago, Ulambayar's family moved from the Hentii province, one of the eastern provinces of Mongolia, to Ulaanbaatar. When he arrived, he worked in his cousin's firm producing blocks and bricks for construction. Now, based on his experience, he would like to start his own brick business.

As the construction industry booms in Mongolia, there is an ever-increasing demand for construction materials including blocks and bricks. He requests a loan to purchase the necessary equipment to make blocks and bricks for construction.

loans.use: To purchase the necessary equipment to make blocks and bricks

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.en:
V. Shuhrat is 25 years old and has been married for about two years. His wife is a housekeeper.

Shuhrat has been running his business for about two years. He rents a retail store where he sells different kinds of housewares. His business is the family’s main source of income. Shuhrat is trying to have a wide range of goods of good quality to meet the requirements of his customers and to satisfy the needs of clients with different levels of income.

Today, Shuhrat requests $3000 for the term of 12 months. This is the first time that Shuhrat has asked for a loan through IMON International and Kiva. It will be used to buy more housewares in order to increase the range of his goods. Due to the profitability of his business, the determination of this micro-entrepreneur and his experience in the business, this customer is qualified to receive this loan.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy new housewares to increase the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Sokhna

texts.fr: Sokhna D., 54 ans est membre de banc villageois de Pout Diack depuis 6 ans et demi. Elle veut renforcer son petit commerce  de poissons frais et de poissons séchés  Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Sokhna D., age 54, has been a member of the village lending group of Pout Diack for six and a half years. She wants to bolster her small business selling fresh fish and dried fish. The loan she's requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell fresh and dried fish

loans.name: Muhabbot

texts.en:
Muhabbot is 55 years old. He is married and the father of 6 children. Muhabbot owns a grocery store and provides for his family with the revenue generated by the grocery store. In addition he buys and sells construction materials with the help of his sons in the construction market. He is requesting a loan of US $2800 for the term to increase the stock of foodstuffs in his grocery store and also for construction materials. 

Muhabbot is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once and awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is that his children progress by means of their studies, for which he is doing his best. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Expand grocery store inventory; construction materials

loans.name: Alpha

texts.fr:
Monsieur Alpha B. est un fonctionnaire qui fait l’embouche au quartier Cite Lamy de Thiès, une ville située 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.  Il va utiliser le crédit qu’il sollicite pour renforcer son activité qui consiste d’élever des moutons pour les revendre.  Il est âgé de 52 ans et il est marie avec des enfants.

Monsieur B. sollicite un produit spécial de l’IMCEC.  Le produit s’appelle Kiva Program de Développement de l’Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF), et il sert à aider les parents des enfants pauvres qui sont dans le projet de Christian Children’s Fund, l’organisation qui a crée IMCEC.  Les clients profitent d’un taux d’intérêt diminué.
texts.en:
Mr. Alpha B. is a civil servant who fattens livestock in the Cite Lamy district of Thiès, a city locate 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. He's going to use the loan to bolster his business, which involves raising sheep for resale. He is 52 and married and has children.

Mr. B. is requesting a special IMCEC product. The product is called "Kiva Program de Développement de l’Enfant et de la Famille" (PDEF). It's used to help the parents of poor children who are with the Christian Children’s Fund, which is the organization that created IMCEC. Clients benefit from a reduced interest rate.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his business involving the raising of sheep

loans.name: Mirzomurod

texts.en:
Mirzomurod is 52 years old, and he has been married since the age of 26 to the mother of his 4 children. Mirzomurod has worked in agriculture since he was young. His father taught him how to responsibly work with each crop, and now, with the help of his wife and adult children, he feels a sense of dignity from his work. As a consequence, he treats each plant with affection and care until they are ready for harvest, at which point he takes them to sell in the market.

Mirzomurod would very much like to buy a house in the city to ensure the well-being and tranquility of his children, and in this way improve his quality of life. The money that he is soliciting is for the purchase of seeds, chemical fertilizers, fuels and lubricants. Let’s support this hard-working and talented man so that he can obtain his goals!

loans.use: Seeds, fertilizer, fuels, and lubricants

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en: Alice N. is a very hardworking lady with a business selling clothes for women, men, and children in her locality. Her previous loan was very successful for her business. She is now seeking a new loan, again from Pearl Microfinance. One of the tangible benefits from her loan is that she bought herself a motorcycle that is making money for her. However she has a plan of buying another motorcycle so as to increase her income since her expenditures keep on increasing as her children join higher classes. Alice seeks a loan to be able to buy more clothes for sale. Alice says this is the right time to stock more clothes that will bring in profits since the school term is ending. And by the time her children go back to school, she will have made enough for their school fees and other school requirements.

loans.use: Buying more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Ndeye Khoudia

texts.fr: Mademoiselle  Ndeye Khoudia N. a commencé le commerce en 2005.  Son activité consiste à vendre des bijoux, tissus, et divers autres marchandises.  Avec ce prêt, elle veut reconstituer son stock pour mieux servir ses clients et gagner un profit.  C’est le quatrième crédit qu’elle a reçu auprès de l’IMCEC et elle a bien remboursé les précédents.  Elle a 39 ans et elle habite à Thiès, une ville située à 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale du Sénégal.  Elle est célibataire et avec les revenus de son entreprise elle se soutient.
texts.en:
Ms. Ndeye Khoudia N. began working in commerce in 2005. Her business involves selling jewelry, fabrics, and various other merchandise. With this loan, she wants to replenish her inventory to serve her customers better and to earn a profit. This is the fourth loan she has received from IMCEC, and she has repaid the preceding ones. She is 39 years old and lives in Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. She is unmarried, and with the revenues from her enterprise, she supports herself.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy jewely, fabrics, and various other goods

loans.name: Sayali

texts.en:
M. Sayali is 36 years old, married, and lives with his wife and 6 children. He has been a farmer for the past 6 years, which he began with the goal of supporting his household and above all to satisfy the needs of his children. For Sayali, agriculture is an activity that he likes to do. Within it, vegetable production is what he likes most as it is easier to cultivate these plants and the product is profitable in season, which is annually.

But the earnings are greater and beneficial for every farmer, especially when buyers purchase the production in great quantities and the expense of transporting the products is avoided as the buyers come to harvest and take them away themselves. Now Sayali wishes to borrow money which he wants to invest in seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants. Be an important part of the growth of Sayali’s business. He is sincerely grateful to all of you.

loans.use: Seeds, fertilizer, fuels, and lubricants

loans.name: Bibizilol

texts.en:
M. Bibizilol has been selling a big variety of foodstuffs in her grocery store for the past 9 years. She is married and has a son. A true entrepreneur, she studies the market to determine client needs and preferences. Industrious and enterprising, Bibizilol is focused on expanding her business. Presently, she has a monthly income of about $400.

Bibizilol is currently seeking a loan for US $3000 for the term of 12 months. She plans to use the loan to increase her assortment of fresh merchandise and expand her business. With the increased sales and profits, Bibizilol hopes to expand her grocery and improve the living standards of her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

loans.use: Expand store inventory

loans.name: Melita

texts.en:
Melita B. is a pig grower. She started her business in 2000 with only one sow. She wants to grow her business even more to support all their needs. Presently, she has two sows and five pigs. She also sells piglets to her friends who are pig growers. She is already a widow and has only one child. She works diligently for the family. Aside from pigs, she owns a small sari-sari (community-based mini grocery) store. She sells variety of goods to supplement her income.

She is requesting a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI, a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to buy piglets to increase the size of her piggery. The loan will also be used to buy additional merchandise for her store.

CEVI is reaching out to more people to start and have their own livelihood. It provides not just loans but also training and insurance benefits to all the clients as well

loans.use: Purchase piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Murodjon

texts.en:
Selling office supplies on the street became the only source of income for N. Murodjon, a humble 28 year-old young man who's been doing this for 4 years. Murodjon is a widower father of 4 children. His children are the reason that he works hard in order to provide them with the best, brightest future. This young man has many projects for his future. The main project is that Murodjon wants to open his own store where he would be able to sell not only office supplies but also a great numbers of books. His wish is to add more office supplies therefore have more to offer to his clients. Murodjon would pay back this loan and with the money he would be able to pay for his children’s education. This young man waits for your help. Let's make his dream come true.

loans.use: Expand store inventory

loans.name: Xekh Niak 21 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe Xekh Niak 21 (Fighting Poverty 21) est composé de cinq femmes dont la plus jeune a 33 ans et la plus âgée a 63 ans. Elles habitent à Thiès, une ville située à 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale du Sénégal. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent la même activité d’aviculture.  Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des poussins, des sacs d’aliments pour les nourrir, et pour payer les vaccins.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30,000 CFA ($60) chaqu’une au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The group Xekh Niak 21 (Fighting Poverty 21) is composed of five women, the youngest is 33 years old and the eldest is 63. They live in Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Sénégal. They know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they do the same work, poultry farming.

With regards to improving and expanding their business, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They intend to use this loan to buy some chicks and sacks of food to feed them and also to pay for vaccines.

The group members each hope to realize an average profit of 30,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profit will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for the family, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chicks, feed, and vaccines

loans.name: Abdunosir

texts.en:
Abdunosir is 23 years old and lives with his wife and three kids in his parent’s home. From a young age he demonstrated a talent for agriculture. Abdunosir has always tried to be very responsible and very content with his farm work. When he finishes caring for his crops, he goes to help his father, because he wants to repay his father’s efforts.

What his father likes best out of the whole agricultural process is the marketing, because he always hopes to get a good price for his crops. But once he gets to the market, he gets a little clumsy and sometimes loses track of the accounting. Abdunosir always tries to help him out with some pointers. The loan Abdunosir now is asking for is to purchase seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants for his varied crops. The loan will greatly improve Abdunosir’s income and his family's living standards.

loans.use: Seeds, mineral fertilizer, fuels, and lubricants

loans.name: Sainurdin

texts.en:
Sainurdin is 28 years old, married and has a son. He is a farmer and grows vegetables, something he has done for 5 years. This is the only thing he knows how to do and what he likes most. For Sainurdin, there is nothing better than being in touch with nature and watching the crops of his labor grow year after year. In addition, Sainurdin raises cattle and his family helps him with his business.

Now he wants to borrow money for purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants in order to grow seasonal vegetables. This is the first loan of Sainurdin from IMON International and Kiva and he promises to repay the current loan without any violations and thanks all lenders for their support.
